Decision expected on Hayes-Morales case 

By DAVID MCLEMORE 
U.S. Atty. Gen. Griffin 
Bell will give a decision on the 
Morales-Haves case within a few weeks, state Atty. Gen. John 
Hill said Friday. 

Hill made his com m ents following an a d d re s s to the T ex a s L au n d ry and 
Drycleaning Assn. convention at the 
Mexico okays inm ate treaty 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
MEXICO CITY — A constitu­ tional am endm ent allowing 
Mexico to comply with the terms of a prisoner-exchange treaty negotiated with the United 
States was published in the offi­ cial gazette Friday and takes effect immediately. 
The treaty was sigm*d last T hanks­ giving and ratified by the M exican 
Senate in December. 
Now it only needs approval by the 
I .S. Senate and an exchange of in ­ struments of ratification to allow U.S. inmates in Mexico and Mexicans jailed in the U nited S ta te s to s e rv e th e rem ainder of their sentences in their homelands. 
Until the constitutional am endm ent was passed. Mexico had no authority to make prisoner exchanges with other countries. 

Amendment 

The amendment, inserted as a p ara­ graph in Article 118 of the Constitution d ealin g with the .Judicial S y ste m , specifies that prisoners must give their consent for exchange. 

U.S. diplomatic sources predict it will take until April for the first ex­ change if the U.S. Senate ratifies the treaty and the U.S. Congress approves enabling legislation. 
The M exican C ongress has e ffec­ tively shelved penal reform legislation submitted as the result of a cam paign led by U.S. inm ates seeking parole from prisons in Mexico. 
Several hundred inmates went on a hunger strike in December in support of the legislation, which would have reinstated parole rights for drug of­ fenders. a privilege taken away by legislation in 187*2. 
There are an estim ated HOO A m er­ icans in Mexican jails, m ost held in connection with d ru g v io latio n s in ­ volving marijuana and cocaine. 
The parole bill was introduced last 
Sept. 7 along with the constitutional am endment by then-President Luis 
Ech eve iris, who left office Din*. 1. 

Hilton Palacio del Rio. 
Hill said he contacted Bell Thursday to urge the new attorney general give careful review to a Hill report on the conviction of form er Castroville Police 
Chief Prank Hayes in connection with the death of Richard Morales. 
“ Boll told m e he would personally review the report and the case and give us a decision within two w eeks,” {{ill said. 

Hill gives President pus transfer conditions, Page 
:i a 
______________________ 

Hill said he had originally sent the report last October to Bell’s predeces­ sor, Edward Levi, with a request that the J u s tic e D e p a rtm e n t p ro se c u te 
“ certain persons” named in the report for violation of federal laws. 

Lev i acknowledged receipt of the re­ port. Hill said, but said he would pass it on for action by the new attorney general. 
Hayes was convicted of aggravated a s s a u lt la st J u ly in the d e a th of 
Morales and sentenced to a tvvo-to-H) year term by a San Angelo jury. 
Morales w as shot to death by Hayes while in the officer’s custody Sept. 14, 
1975. Hayes’ wife. Dorothy, was given a 

 one-year probated sentence in July for taking M orales’ body and burying it in a shallow East Texas grave. 
Hill would not sp e cu la te on what 
Bell s decision would be, but added In* still felt the e x tra o rd in a ry c irc u m ­ stances of the ease demanded federal prosecution. 
In bis sp e ec h to the 'ILD A . Hill stressed his continuing battle to com ­ bat tin* flow of Mexican heroin into tin* 

U.S. via Texas. 
Ile said Bell is also a r r a n g in g a m eeting between tin* state attorneys g en eral of Now Mexico, C alifornia, 
Arizona and Texas to discuss m eans by w hich the h ero in can In* stopped 
Hill also said lie discussed with Drug 
E n fo rc e m e n t A d m in is tra tio n Chief 
Steve Benzinger plans to step up a program for eradication of tin* poppy fields i i i Mexico. 
9-inning dinner 

MIAMI (A P ) — The g u ests round first base, picking up a glass of champagne aud a bit of caviar. 

Speeding toward second, they’re greeted by a display of trophies. 

Waiting at third base are 17 waiters. 

I fs all part of the University of 
Miami’s plan to raise money to help pay for the school’s new baseball sta d iu m . At least 31 g u ests will attend the Feb. Hi gourmet diniier-on the-inlield. 

Dress is black tie and tickets are 
$5,DUO per person. 

"It’s the highest-priced dinner in the history of mankind.” said baseball Coach Ron Fraser, who developed the idea. “ I don’t even know if any president has had a dinner like this. I just hope we don’t get any flaming brandy on the rug.”

Murder suspect walks out of jail 

 l l die in fEl’ collision 

CHICAGO (AP) — At least ll p e r­ sons were killed and m ore than 2oo injured F rid a y when one ru sh -h o u r elevated train slam m ed into the back of another one stopped on tilt* tracks, sending cars and passengers plunging into the strt*et below, authorities said. 

“ People fell out of the train and the train fell on top of them .” a witness said. 

The crash occurred in the heart of tile downtown business district. 

Ambulances flooded into the area as crews struggled with saws and torches to free trapped passengers. 
Sharp turn 
The crash, coming ut the* end of a storm that dumped nearly four inches of snow on the city, occurred about 5:3o p.m. as the train rounded a sharp turn tin trucks that form the northeastern arc of Chicago’s Loop. 
Three ears of the tram , headed for the w e ste rn s u b u rb of O ak P a r k , plunged from the tracks into the stm*t and a fourth was piled ato p one of them. 
Police appealed to all doctors living

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS N EW S 

AUSTIN — A man charged with killing an Austin woman and one of two teen-aged girls whose skeletal remains were found near Kerrville escaped from custody here Friday. 
Lt. Joe Jordan of the Austin hom i­ 

 cide b u reau said the m a n , Lyle RI- chard B ru m m e t, 2o, of A ustin, was allowed to go to an unguarded b ath ­ room from a police interrogation room 
Friday afternoon. 

Jordan theorized B rum m et left tin* m e n ’s room , went down a co rrid o r, took the elevator to the ground floor and left Austin police h e a d q u a rte rs unnoticed. 

Brummet had ('artier in the day been tran sp o rted to K errville because lie had told investigators he could lead them to another grave, Austin police reported. 

After no such grave was found in 
Kerr County, B rum m et was taken back to Austin, where he underwent ques­ tioning in the interrogation room prior to Ids escape. Jordan said. 

When told B ru m m e t had e sca p ed only hours after the search, Dist Ally. 
Joe T uck, of K errville, said, “ Good 
Lord. I c a n ’t believe it. T h e w hole thing might have been a ruse to got out of jail.” 

Brum m et had been in Austin police custody since last sum m er after being ch a rg ed with capital m u rd e r in the strangulation death of Diam* K. Ro­ berts, 22, of Austin. 

Tuck said B rum m et had agreed to testify ag a in st a co m p an io n , Allen 
Ladd Woody, It), iii connection with tin* 1975 deaths of two Kerrville teen­ agers. whose bodies were discovered i i i a Kerr County field last August 

Woody’s trial on charges lie killed 
15-year-old Mary Beth Pearson is set for March 28 in Kerrville. 

Agreed to testily 

University of Texas at Austin Athletic Dir. Darrell Royal Friday recalls a happy moment with the late 
Hondo Crouch, the Luckenbach mayor. Royal spoke at opening ceremonies of the I 977 Great Country 
Festival, which was dedicated to Crouch. Royal, the former UT football coach, also was made a festival honorary mayor. The festival continues noon to I I p.m. Saturday “ and noon to 1o p.m. Sunday along the downtown River Walk. It is sponsored by the Paseo del Rio Assn. and radio station KKYX. — Staff photo by Steve Campbell

August.

Argentine death list smuggled to 
United States 

WASHINGTON — Not long ago, Argentina’s handsome, musta­ chioed m ilitary dictator, Gen. Jorge Y’idela, assured Pope Paul m elodram atically that his government was dedicated to defending 
“ human life against any unjust aggression which might end it or curtail its dignity.” 

Y e t w e h a v e j u s t r e c e i v e d a d e a t h list, s m u g g l e d to us f r o m in si d e Vide- l a ’s g o v e r n m e n t . 
It c o n t a i n s t h e n a m e s of s e v e r a l p r o m in e n t A r g e n t i n i a n s w h o m the m i ­ l it a r y .junta a l l e g e d l y w o u l d like e li ­ m in a ted . 
T h e list w a s b ro u g h t to us by c o u r ­ iers who ri sk ed t h e i r own lives in the hope that we w ou ld r a i s e e n o u g h c l a ­ m o r to s a v e th e (loomed p r i s o n e r s . 
Not radicals 
T h e c o u r i e r s a r e not r a d i c a l s , with political m o ti v e s , b u t A r g e n t in i a n offi­ cials a n d c l e r g y m e n . 
E v e n o n e U . S . d i p l o m a t q u i e t l y helpe d the i n t e r m e d i a r i e s s m u g g l e th e 
(leat ii list to us. 
P a r t of t h e l i s t . a p p a r e n t l y , w a s w ritte n in invisible ink on a p a g e of an innocent book a n d e n t r u s t e d to an air t rav ele r.

We r e p o r t e d last O c t o b e r 111 t h at A r ­ g e n t i n a h a d b e c o m e o n e of th e m o s t d a n g e r o u s , m o s t c h a o t i c c o u n t r i e s on e ar th . K i d n a p in g s , ki lli ngs a n d t o r tu r e a r c daily o c c u r r e n c e s . 
“ M o re pe op le a r e killed in one y e a r in A r g e n t i n a . " one S t a te D e p a r t m e n t s o u rc e told us, " t h a n in five y e a r s in

T h e l e g i s l a t i o n w o u l d a u t h o r i z e 
C a r te r to propose r e o rg a n iza tio n p l a n s that would a u t o m a t i c a l l y t a k e e f fe c t unless vetoed by c it h e r b r a n c h of C o n ­ g r e s s w it Inn Btl day s. 
Blueprint 

T h e P r e s i d e n t ' s b l u e p r i n t w o u l d pe rm it him, subject to veto, to t r a n s f e r all or part of an a g e n c y ' s fu n c ti o n s to ano ther, abolish functions, c o n s o lid a te a c t i v i t i e s of s e v e r a l a g e n c i e s a n d c h a n g e a g e n c y n a m e s . 
H e c o u l d n e i t h e r c r e a t e n o r a b o l i s h C a b i n e t d e p a r t m e n t s , nor could he co n so lid ate two or m o r e d e p a r t m e n t s into one. 
T h e P r e s i d e n t told r e p o r t e r s at the 
White Ho us e th at " t h i s is a c o m m i t ­ m e n t t h a t I m a d e in h u n d r e d s of s p e e c h e s a r o u n d th e c o u n t r y d u r i n g the two-year c a m p a i g n 
It w a s on e of the m a j o r re as o n s I wa s ele cte d " 
But lie e m p h a s i z e d that any r e s u l t ­ i n g p e r s o n n e l r e d u c t i o n s w o u l d b e achiev ed th ro u g h attrition an d not b r ­ im's

City Council chilly to sick pay bills 

Reeorrls indicate 2+1o1 personnel had sick lea re accumula­ tion totaling 19o+472 days 

By DEBORAH W ESER 

Mayor Pro Tem Henry Cis­ neros said Friday City Council has agreed not to support any of the sick pay bills in the state legislative hopper. 

“ We have a good reaso n for not choosing one. We don’t have dollar fi­ gures for the various options,” he de­ clared. 

The council decision was m ade late 
Thursday in a closed door huddle with top city staff. 

Cisneros took the lid off the closed- door conference Friday in light of re­ ports the city’s failure to respond with su p p o rt has d raw n s h a rp co m m en t from State Sen. Frank Lombardino. 
Other council m em bers confirm ed the gist of the reported non-support decision but refused to provide details. 
City officials insist a critical budget d ra in h as been c r e a te d by a 1975 am endm ent that allows fire fighters and police officers to accrue unlimited sick leave at the rate of 15 days a year. 
On retirem ent or when leaving ser­ vice, they are paid a lump sum for all unused sick leave under that act. 
Lombardino is the author of four new 

 bills offering options for rem edying the unlimited sick leave accrual diffi­ culty the city claim s to be in. 
Fund drain 

L om b ard in o played a key role in bringing San Antonio under the 1975 legislation lifting the previous 9o-day accrual ceiling. 
Lombardino’s new bill offer options ranging from a reaffirm ation of the unlimited sick leave situation through 

 return to the old 9o-day ceiling or top­ ping accrual at a new 12o-day limit 
City staff, Cisneros noted, still has detailed assessm ent to do on each of the options and several variations be­ fore council is prepared to offer any opinion on the bills. 
The bill suggesting a return to the 
9o-day ceiling also calls for a g ran d ­ father clause protecting those fire and police p ersonnel who alre ad y have more than 9o days to their credit. 

City Hall staff, meanwhile, has pro­ duced exact figures on city obligations under several sick pay accrual options for fire fighters and police officers on the m unicipal payroll as of Dee. 31, 
197o. 
Their records indicate 2,1o1 fire and police personnel had sil k leave accu­ mulation totalling 199,472 days 
Obligations 

The city has an $11,935,975.57 obli­ gation for those days under the unli­ mited accrual system lf the ceiling of 12o days is imposed, the c i t y ’s o b lig a tio n d ro p s to 
$8,3o4,752.42. 

With the old 9o-day ceiling back in place — but no g ra n d f a th e r cla u se p ro tectio n , th e ob lig atio n d ro p s to 
$o,987,848.29. 

A large individual account of $48,87o, for example, would drop to $14,941 at 
12o days and to $11,2o5 at 9o days. 

An account of $35,889, goes to $11,2o9 or to $8,4o8 at the 9o-day limit and an account of $22,143 is reduced to $9,348 at 12o days or $7,o11 at 9o days. The new figures have been prepared to as­ sist City Mgr. Tom lluebner and City 
Council in assessing the economic im ­ pact of sick pay legislation pending and proposed. 
Goodwill picks '77 w orker o f year 

By SARA MARTINEZ 
Two years ago, Theresa Lott was defined “ unemployable” by her clinical psychologist. But 
Theresa’s hard work and deter­ mination have made her the 1977 
Goodwill Worker of the Year. 

Theresa is a paraplegic employed as a te le p h o n e o p e r a to r at G oodw ill 
R ehabilitation Service. She was hon­ ored at th e a n n u a l M e e tin g and 
Awards Luncheon Friday. 
R unners-up w ere M aria A b rah am and Connie Jaram illo, both victims of cerebral palsy. 
“ The Goodwill people are doing good 
-work but they m ust be supported not only by the local government, but by the private sector also,” said Mayor 
Pro Tem Henry Cisneros. 
Award 

Cisneros was a receipient of a Com­ munity Service Award. Texas Rehabi­ litation Com m . J e ss Irwin and Gov. 
Dolph B riscoe w ere the o th er r e c i­ pients. 
“ I’m honored for being served with this aw a rd ,” Cisneros said. ‘‘It is a symbol of what local government can and should do. 
“ We cannot forget that the h an d i­ capped deserve our attention and care as m uch as anyone e ls e ,” C isneros said. “ This plaque will help m e not to forget.” 
John Poerner of the Governor’s Of­ fice a c c e p te d th e a w a rd for Gov. 
Briscoe. 
Sam Millsap Sr., blind Sun Antonio businessman, was elected to a record fifth term as president of the Goodwill 
B oard of D ir e c to rs at th e F r id a y meeting. 
Fourteen directors were selected for a three-year term . New directors are 
N ancy B o h n ian , C arol D ic k e rs o n , 
M aj.Gen. Bill H arris, Dr. David J a ­ cobson, Charles O. Kilpatrick, Charles 
S. Nelson. Manuel M. Pena Jr., C. W. 
Pope, Henry A. Reed, Leonic Reeves, 
Vernon Shade, Donald Schaffer and 
Bruce Waltz. 

Shaw’s use of aide questioned 

THERESA LOTT accepts her a w a rd from G o o d w ill President 
Sam M illsa p Sr., center, and Bob Blase, executive director 

By BEN KING Jr. 
County Tax Assessor-Colleetor 
Ben Shaw’s use of Joe Hainey 
Manion as his top assistant could make Bexar County liable for large financial losses, county officials warned Friday. 

County Com s. A lbert B u s ta m a n te and T om S to lh a n d s k e said S h a w 's practice of letting Manion fill in for him when he’s out of town could raise serious legal questions because M an­ ion is not a county employe. 
Those questions are currently being researched by the district attorney’s office, Stolhandkse said. 
Concern 
The com m issioners’ main concern is 
Manion is not bonded and. as a result, the county would be liable if he is sued because of a decision he m ade while acting as tax assessor-collect or. 
Manion ran against Shaw for the tax post in the Democratic prim ary, but later supported Shaw' in the runoff race against former Tax Assessor-Colleetor 
Charles Davis. 
After Shaw took office Jan I. Man­ ion became acting chief deputy. How­ ever, he only receives a $1 a year sa­ lary from Shaw. Manion receives no salary from the county. 
Hill gives President gas transfer conditions 

State Atty. Gen. John Hill said Friday he has told President C arter he would oppose any transfer of natural gas from Texas if it will hurt Texans. 

Hill told rep o rters he had wired 
President C arter Texas would cooper­ ate with em ergency energy legislation signed Wednesday by Carter if three 

 conditions were met. 
The conditions arc: There must be no injury to Texans as a result of any fu tu re g a s t r a n s f e r o u t-o f-sta te . 
“ W e’ve suffered enough from gas shortages,** Hill said. 

The price for gas paid by interstate customers must not be less than that paid by Texas customers. 
Extra police may walk city again within week 

Extra police foot patrols will probably be back on duty by next week, a Downtown, Inc., official said Friday. 

Ed Harllee, executive vice president of the downtown m e rch an ts asso cia­ tion, said he based his belief on talks he had Friday with Police Chief E. E. 
B riscoe aids 
Hernandez’ bid 

State Rep. Joe Hernandez of San 
Antonio has received the support of 
Gov. Dolph Briscoe in his bid to be­ ltline the top federal prosecutor in the 
Western District of Texas. 
H e rn a n d e z c o n firm e d 
F rid a y 
Briscoe has sent a letter to President 
Jim m y Carter recommending him for 
E S. attorney. 
U.S. Atty. John E. Clark, a Republi­ can, presently holds the post. 
Hernandez said he has also received the support of Texas House Speaker 
Billy Clayton. 
San Antonio attorney W arren Weir and U.S. M agistrate Jam ie Boyd of El 
Paso have also been m entioned as contenders for the $39,8oo |>er year 
|Klst. 
Another name frequently mentioned is Asst. U.S. Atty. Jerem iah Handy, a 
IU-vear veteran of the office. 

Peters and a representative of the city m anager’s office. 
“ I’m confident the patrols will be back on the street prior to the start of the San A ntonio Stock Show next week,” Harllee said. 
“ I f s a feeling I got out of the m eet­ ing with Chief Peters and city officials. 
From all indications, I feel the city funding will bi* worked out.” 
Cut forced 

Police foot patrols w ere cut by a l­ most a third in January when SAPD’s share of revenue sharing funds for the patrols ran out. 
Chief Peters said statistics indicated a jum p in downtown crim e in January over Hie preceding month, but de­ clined to say the increase was directly related to the patrol cutback. 
“ It s hard to say just how much in­ crease there has been in crim e down­ town since the cutback in foot patrols,” 
Peters said. 
“ The figures for January showed an in c rease, over D ecem b er, but then 
D e c e m b e r w as low c o m p a r e d to 
October. 
"B ut I c a n ’t help feel that we will feel the loss of the patrols over a period of tim e.” 
Unruliness 
Harllee said downtown m erc h an ts have noticed an increase in unruly ac­ tivity downtown. “ We truly feel it will gel worse without the extra patrolmen. 

"I believe the cold weather has been responsible for keeping the trouble down.” 
H arllee said downtown m erch an ts wanted the extra foot patrols back for preventive security. 
“ The visibility is the main thing.” lie said. “ J u s t th a t e x tra u n ifo rm downtown helps keep potential trouble from happening. 
“ It’s just com m on sense that it s b etter to stop c rim e before it gets started.”

City 
Council m em bers — Glen Hartm an and Bob 
Billa — filed Friday as candidates in the April 2 municipal election. 
H artm an, 47 and a retired civil ser­ vant, filed for the slot in District 9 where he now lives on the North Side. 
His cam paign treasurer is Valdemar 
P. Pere*. 
H artm an and Billa chose to submit the req u ired 1oo-signature petition signed by registered voters in their respective districts rather than the 
HOO filing fee. 
Both men were elected two years ago us m em bers of the victorious majority 
Independent Team slate at City Hall. 
Their interests have pushed them in markedly different voting directions d u rin g the c u rre n t tw o-year te rm although they started out as running males

South Side D istrict 3 aud will have

EPA rules criticized by official 

The recent em issions offset ruling by the U.S. E n v iro n m en tal P ro tectio n 
Agency may harm San Antonio’s ef­ forts towards industrial development. a G reater S a n Antonio C ham ber of 
Com m erce official said Friday. 
“ This ruling already has stopped construction of a 5,ooo-employe auto­ motive plant iii Oklahoma City and has prevented the Texas Seadock project, an offshore oil unloading facility, from being developed,” said Bill O ’Connell, 
■chairman of the ch am b er's urban af­ fairs council. 
The EPA ruling affect* industrial growth in parts of the country that are not presently attaining national air quality standards. 
New large-scale industrial plants or large expansions to existing plants will he p erm itted only when em issions from existing sources nearby are re­ duced by ail am ount equal to new emission*. 
“ The cham ber has asked City Coun­ cil to pass a resolution op|x»sing this unreasonable regulation,” O’Connell said. 
“ It could prevent any future large employers from developing plants in this area,” he explained. 
He a d d e d , “ The cham ber will o p p o s e this ruling in written com m ents to the 
EPA and will ask that it be rescinded when we testify before an EPA hearing panel in Dallas on March I.”

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Feb 5 1977 
Shivering East gets a break 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
The long-shivering East Coast got a brief respite from the cold on Friday. 

But f o r e c a s te r s w a rn e d of new w e a th er p ro b lem s ahead, including another possible blizzard in hard-hit 
Buffalo, N.Y. 
The warning cam e as natural gas, d iverted from ‘he West u n d e r P r e ­ sident C arter’s emergency energy bill, was moving toward fuel-starved areas in the East and Midwest which were trying to recover from last weekend’s snows and cold. Homes and hospitals have first claim on the n atu ral gas, however, so the additional supplies w ere not expected to provide m uch help for closed factories and b u s in ­ esses. 
Columbia Gas T ransm ission Corp. announced at Charleston, W.Va., that heavy dem and on its natural gas re- 

"Everybody in the East is after the same gas, but there's not a whole lot out there.' 

 serv es had red u ced its a b ility to deliver gas to the 8o retail utilities it serves in seven Eastern states and the 
District of Columbia. 
Action 
“ This action means that should ex­ tremely cold weather occur during the next two months, retail gas companies served by the transm ission ^company will be forced to implement emergency c u rta ilm e n t ac tiv ity at a h ig h e r te m p eratu re than in the p a s t,” the company said. 
It said its gas company custom ers already were “ at a point where the gas they now have available for their sea­ sonal a llo ca tio n s from C o lu m b ia 
Transmission for the rest of the winter 

 will only m eet the essential hum an needs of their customers with normal weather.” 
Torn Hauek, public relations director for the company, said the em ergency energy law will help. “ But we still must go out and find it, contract for it and arrange for shipment. Everybody in the East is after the sam e gas, but there ain’t a whole lot out there.’’ 
The w ea th er b u re a u said e a rly 
Friday that tem peratures in the ea s­ tern United States were at near-normal levels. But the forecasters also said a new su rg e of u n se a so n a b ly cold weather threatened to move into the area by Saturday. 
Then, Friday afternoon, the National 
W eath er S erv ice issu ed a s p e c ia l 

 report, predicting blizzard conditions throughout most of western New York, beginning Saturday and continuing in­ to Sunday. 
Strong winds, coupled with snow or snow sq u a lls, w ere e x p e c te d to produce the blizzard co n d itio n s in western New York. Wind chill te m ­ peratures could reach m inus 3o, the weather report stated. 
Schools 
7New York State Gov. Hugh C arey's office announced that more than 1,ooo schools closed this week because of the natural gas shortage, will be allowed to reopen next week. More than half a million pupils were involved. 
At the sam e tim e, C arey im posed new gas conservation s ta n d a rd s for large commercial users across most of upstate New York, requiring them to cut fuel usage to 75 per cent of normal. 
He urged voluntary conservation by smaller commercial customers.

Uniform burnings protest ERA stand 

Israelis turn to patience 

JE R U S A L E M - I s ­ ra e l, w hich had been very insistent earlier that the Syrians m ust vacate their positions in south­ ern Lebanon, softened its stand Friday into one of patient watchfulness. 
The Israelis may have had patience urged on

AUSTIN (AP) - Two Girl Scout leaders stood in their fashionable neighborhood Friday and burned their uniforms lo protest the organization’s support of the Equal Rights A m end­ ment. 
“ It hurts me very deeply to have to do this,” said Mary Ann Holm an, a 
44-year-old mother of four and a Girl 
Scout leader for 18 years, before she dropped hor green uniform in a blaz­ ing trash can. 
Mrs. Holman said she and Dot Sehe- dler, a 4o-year-old mother of three Girl 
Scouts, resigned from the g ro u p to protest the national board of directors' recent endorsement of the ERA. 
Violation 
“ I wish we had some cookies, we d throw them in there (the fire) too,” said Mrs. Holman, a m em ber of the 
Lone Star Girl Scout Council board of directors. 
Mrs. Holman, whose two daughters were Girl Scouts, said the endorsement w as in violation of th e G irl Scout charter since the group is a nonprofit organization and is not supposed to take sides in political issues. 
Mrs. Holman’s and Mrs. Schedler’s daughters are now grown and are no 

 longer in the Girl Scouts. 
“ I took this action because I ’ve tried to work through the sy stem 
But I failed to get enough votes on the local board to support a reprim and of the national board for endorsing a political issue in violation of our charter,” Mrs. 
Holman said. 
National 

Wanda Rice, executive d irecto r of the Lone Star Girl Scout Council, said the protest was directed at a national issue and would have no bearing on the local group, which she said is not under control of the national board. 
"Our local board has established no position, one way or the other, on the 
ERA,” she said. 
M rs. H olm an ch a rg e d that th e fem inist m ovem ent and one of its le a d e rs, N ational O rg a n iz atio n of 
Women founder Betty F riedan. who is also a m em ber of the national Girl 
Scout board, are “ more and more di­ rec tin g the co u rse of th e sco u tin g movement." 
In S a v a n n a h , G a., b ir th p la c e of 
American Girl Scout founder Juliette 
Gordon Lowe, an a n t i - ERA g r o i p called for a boycott of Girl Scout coo­ kies.

 freeze public for $15 billion 

WASHINGTON 
(AP) 
- 
The 
KTverse winter weather could cost 
\mericans as much as $15 billion in personal income, congressmen study­ ing President Carter s economic stimulus program were told Friday. 
Economists representing a range of 
(pinion gave their estimates to con­ gressional committees, hut did not agree us to whether Carter’s two-year, 
531.2-billioti package should be enacted intact, enlarged, reduced or rest rue- lured. 
One of the gloomiest assessments came from Michael K. Evans, p re ­ sident of Chuse Econom etric As­ sociates, an economic research and advisory firm. 
“ About $8.5 billion iii personal in­ come will be lost this year due to the cold weather,” he told the House Ways and Means Committee, adding that "if the cold spell were to continue through the end of February and drought con­ ditions were to affect tile Plains states, the net loss could be as large as $15 billion.” 
Fuel costs 

E vans’ basic estimate of income reduction included $2.5 billion because of greater fuel consumption, $2.5 bil­ lion because of higher fuel prices. $1.5 billion from the laying off of 5o11,ooo 

 workers and $2 billion because of higher fruit and vegetable prices. 
Walter W. Heller. University of 
Minnesota professor and form er chairman of the Council of Economic 
Adv isers, told the committee higher heating costs and layoffs would be equivalent to canceling about half the effect of the $11.4 billion Carter proposed in the form of $5o tax rebates and other payments to nearly all 
Americans. 
Speaking for the United Auto 
Workers. Howard Young estimated that “ higher fuel bills, are extracting 
$5o to $1oo from the spendable income of millions of families in hard-hit areas 
... as much as 4o per cent of the proposed rebate ... will be soaked up.” 
Caution 
However, Reginald ll. Jones, chair­ man of the General Electric Co., while agreeing that the bitter w inter strengthens the ease for some govern­ ment aid lo the economy, cautioned against 
“ overreaction or excessive concentration on the problems peculiar to this cold, cold w inter.” 
“ Business experience suggests that much of Hic buying lost this winter w ill be made up with the return of decent weather, 
.Jones said. “ Most orders have been delayed, not lost.” 
Raza Unida claims 
Muniz is punished 

AUSTIN (AP) - The 
Raza 
Cnida 
Party claimed today that Ram­ sey Muniz is being pun­ ished in court because Ik* ran for governor in 1972 and 1974. 
The statem ent was released by Angelica 
Martinez, Austin, who said she was “ press secretary” of tile state party. 
Muniz. 
34-year-old 
Corpus Christi lawyer, pleaded guilty Wednes­ day in a San Antonio federal court to conspiracy in a m a r ­ ijuana smuggling case. 
He faces a possible five- year prison sentence and a $15,(KIO fine. No date for sentencing has been set. 
“ The Raza Cnida Par­ ty holds, the very strong view that it would have been virtually impossible for Ramsey Muniz to receive a fair and .inst trial iii San Antonio.” tile statement said. “ We think that a tremendous amount of pressure was brought to bear upon 

Ramsey Muniz to compel him and coerce him to opt for a plea bargain, rather than to trust iii the federal government and 
Texas’ particular form of justice.” 
The statment said that 
Muniz was “ kidnaped, beaten and tortured in 
Mexico for two days by 
Mexican law enforcers. 
Officers from the Drug 
Enforcement Agency of the United State's were present, although there were never a un formal papers submitted to ex­ tradite. Ramsey Muniz 

 was repeatedly told dur­ ing this brutal episode that the Raza Cnida Par­ ty was to be destroyed.” 
“ We feel 
Ramsey 
Muniz’s rights have been grossly disregarded. We feel he is not being cas­ tigated for the conspiracy charges, but for his can­ didacies as the guberna­ torial contender for Lu 
Raza Cnida Party in 1972 and 1974. through these political trials, the chief aim being to destroy and discredit the entire Texas 
Chicano movement." the statement said.

LAREDO 
(A P) 
- 
Health officials in this border city said Friday the outbreak of rabies that has plagueu the city since November has peaked, but officials in other cities along the Rio 
Grande announced mas­ sive vaccination cam ­ paigns. 
“ This thing has made 

 the public very conscious 
Of rabies,” said Richard 
Leopold, director of pub­ lic health in Brownsville, about 2oo miles down the river. 

 a bat found later to have rabies. 
In 
Laredo, health educator Victor Oliveros said authorities were confident that the out­ break has “ peaked.” 
He said only one posi­ tive case had been reported this month, bringing the total since 
November to 47. Sixteen 

 humans have been treat­ ed. 
Oliveros said more than 
14,ooo dogs have been vaccinated since the campaign began. 
Police officers were told to shoot on sight dogs that may appear to have rabies. The city also asked for permission to use special poison.

M anaging Editor 

Lom bardino presses council to help him 

S t a t e S e n . F r a n k L o m b a r ­ dino is trying to cut a deal with 
C ity Council to get him off the political hot s p o t . T h e m a n e u ­ vering has c o m e close to a poli­ tical shakedown. 

City Council r epresenta tiv es met w ith tht* senator earlier (see editorial in this sp a c e on Jan. 
29). They agreed inform ally to g iv e Lom bardino s o m e m ethod to sa ve face on the controversial sic k -le a v e bill in e x c h a n g e for his help during the current le­ gislative session. 

That such a discussion would even take place is shocking. 
Meanwhile. Lombardino has been trying to get the council to take a position on the sick-pav dispute. This week, a proposal ta a r b i t r a t e w a s d i s c u s s e d a m o n g c o u n c il m e m b e r s even t h o u g h 
City 
A t t o r n e y 
J i m 
Parker advised that the issue is a m atter of law, not subject to arbitration. 
C o n t r a r y l e g a l a d v i c e h a s b e e n o f f e r e d , a p p a r e n t l y , b e ­ ca u se 4 s o m e c o u n c il m e m b e r s believe they can arbitrate* le g a l­ ly. There is. indeed, a school of m unicipal law which holds that a home* rule f i t \ e*an do anything it isn t s t e p p e d fr o m d o i n g . 
There are still a f'*vv who prac­ tice that kind of la w . 
But if arbit rat ion h a s a n y validity at all, public opinion s h o u l d h a v e a v o i c e in it. 
Therefore, we propose that the* c o u n c i l put on th e A p ril c it y e l e c t i o n b a llo t th e s i c k - l e a v e issue. Such a referenelum would g iv e a clear view of whether the* taxpayers of San Antonio want to obligate t h e m s e lv e s to tin* pro­ gram . rile* r eferen d u m should pro­ vide* fur an e x p r e ssio n on sie*k leav e* for all e m p lo y e s, also. rile* sick-pay issue* is too e x ­ pensive* to leave tee the* employe* union leaders and Lombardino. 
L o m b a n l i n o b a f f l e s us fu r th e r by o f f e r i n g to p u sh a m u ltip le ch o ic e in the L e g i s l a ­ 

 ture — he introduced bills last w e e k o f f e r i n g fo ur d i f f e r e n t ways out of the sick-leave fuss. 
But that w as A F T E R he publicly pledged to abide by an opinion poll he w a s conducting. It w a s a l s o a f t e r th e E x p r e s s - N e w s moved to insure a citywide poll in ste a d of a L o m b a r d i n o - c o n - trolled poll in a selected neig h­ borhood in tilt* city. 
L o m b a r d i n o is d o u b le - dealing. 
There is a way to resolve the dispute and. at the s a m e tim e, establish fairness in city labor p r a c t i c e s . Council sh o u ld ask 
Lom bardino to repeal the sick- le a v e law that a p p l i e s to San 
Antonio. 
T hen t h e r e sh o u ld be a r e ­ view of pay and benefits for city e m p l o y e s . If f i r e f i g h t e r s and police officers need a special la­ bor policy, lot it be worked out openly. If it takes a bonus to at­ tract and hold e m p lo y e s, put it in the contract. 
If r e t i r e e s n e e d i m p r o v e ­ m ents on their pensions, includ­ ing c o v e r a g e for h ealth i n s u r ­ a n c e , s e e w h a t c a n be d o n e about that 
But let's stop the funny b u s i­ n e s s b a c k sta g e , the legislating to load up tin* city budget, the c o m p r o m is in g to keep L om b a r ­ dino from taking legislative re­ p r i s a ls a g a in s t the c i t y ’s t a x ­ payers and any other d e m e a n in g conduct of the c ity ’s business. 
We regret that the Police and 
F i r e D e p a r t m e n t s a r e b e i n g caught up in what is essentially a raid on the city treasury and the taxpayers. We believe d eep ­ ly that tin* m ost-beneficial wav- out of the dispute is to start over and d e v e l o p so u n d p a y - a m l- benefits plans for those d epa rt­ m ents, as well as any other d e ­ partment that lacks them. 
L o m b a r d i n o ’s p o litica l use- 
I il ln e s s is s e r i o u s l y c o m p r o ­ m ised. City Council, under the im pressio n it m ust m ollify the senator, s h o u ld n ’t labor under illusions. 

(loim sellor wauls long-term stall 

P r e s i d e n t 
( a r t e r s e n t a handwritten note to his top staff aides this week. 
Ile asked them lo spend “ an adequate amount of t i m e ” with t h e i r f a m i l i e s b e c a u s e th e y would bt* m ore valuable to tin* 
President and to the country if they are rested and have a sta­ ble family situation. Full-tim e work would be for e m e r g e n c ies. he said. l’he note s m e s s a g e isn t ori­ ginal for people iii a p r e ssu r e situ a tio n 
F a m i l y c o u n s e l l o r s use that advice as standard and they g i v e it to p erso n s in jobs s u b j e c t to u n u s u a l d e m a n d s upon their time. 

‘Yessir, this is your taxpayer-supplied limousine — would you mind slipping in back; we have to pick up Mr. Vance on the way. 
Heinl in error 

The reason Mr. ( arter gave s h o u l d g i v e h is o p p o s i t i o n a start, 'riu* P resident wrote: “ We are going to be here a long tim e, and all of you will be m ore val­ uable to m e and the country w ith rest and a s t a b l e h o m e life." 

Just a few d a y s e a r lie r , he had told Vice President Mondale to go hom e and get s o m e sleep 
— that Mr. M a n d a te s report 
11 tun f o r e i g n h e a d s of s t a t e could wait. 

Best m a n a g e m e n t p ractices a g ree with the Carter formula. 
G ood w o r k isn t s y n o n y m o u s w itll busv-ness. 

Sir: (HI 
Robert I). Heinl .lr. has hone it again (Jan. 29 article on Tokyo 
Rose) vs itll half-truths auf! broad li­ berty of loose words. 
There were six females on Radio 
Tokyo during World War ll — not one. 
Miss Iva Toyuri was not “captured” in 
1946, hut questioned and released by the U.S. Army, Miss Toyuri’s story has been confirmed by the U.S. State De­ partment and was aired on “ (in Min­ utes” on UBS (Channel 5). 
Why is Ibis type article allowed on your editorial page? Fiction belongs in the comics section. 
Joespli F. Ileinzle 

Another option on sick leave 

Sir: I have just marked and mailed my ballot to the Lombardino Poll on firemen and policemen sick leave. 
However, I believe that there is an­ other option. 
Why can’t sick leave be for sickness? 
Suppose a special fund were set up based on a percentage of payroll thai would reflect I In- normal incidence of temporary physical incapacities. When one is too ill to report, he may. when he returns, apply for sick leave pay co­ vering the time of hts incapacity. 
Leave would be unlimited to cover not only short-term sickness but also ex­ tended hospitalizations following an accident or serious illness. 
This plan has been used successfully in some school systems. It appeals to the sense of fair play, honesty, and participation. Employes can he repre- sented on the committee to approve sic k leave applications. 
Accumulation of moneys iii the fund should not he cause for alarm. Unex­ pected heart attacks, cancer or serious accidents mean long-term drains on the fund. 
B E W . 

One wonders about criticism 

Sir . One c annot help but vc under about th** purpose of Edna llobun’s critic ism of President Carter (Letters.

 iii a letter undoubtedly written be­ ton* tin* inauguration, she criticized the President of his choice of clothing,

‘Which would you like first, the report on the econ­ omy or the weather?’ 
Budgeteer® err on military 

W A S H I N G T O N - As you m a k e up y o u r m i n d w h i c h a rm ed service you want to join, it m ig ht pay you to stop by the new Congressional Budget Of­ fice (CBG) before you visit the recruiter. 
Headed by Dr Alice K u lm , the 
CBG has jus! issued a probing report which examines recruit training iii the Armed Forces. 
The Marines, reports Dr Riving do it longest (12 weeks), the Air Force does it shortest (6 weeks) The Air 
Force also does It easiest (ET hours jM*r week), the Marines do ll hardest 
(HD hours). The Navy does it cheapest 
($8o a week JMT recruit), the Army does it highest ($14o). 
From these and a m ultitude of other numbers, the CBG concludes the four Armed Services could save 
5o (too in total manpower and close lo 
$4oo million each year in (heir bill for training 
As might be expected, with I rain­ ing the principal productive activity of military forces in peacetime. Us costs in dollars and manpower arc* considerable 

Iii 1977. IS per cent of U S military manpower is devoted to training the other K2 per cent at an annual cost exceeding $8 2 billion 
AII four service's train new recruits at two levels: baste and advanced, the first of which makes him a military man, the Stroud of which gives him a skill, 
The process averages out at 17 weeks across the hoard or all ser­ vices. but there the similarities stoic 
The .Murines devote over 19 weeks to the whole process, compared with the Army's 18 
The two highly technical, mater- lul-oriented services Navy and Air 
Force (who theoretically ought to be close together) are at opposite poles: 
To com plete an airman's training requires 21 weeks, a sailor (who may well also be* an airman) gets through in 15 weeks. 
Navy cheapest 
'Depending on whet tier you call It efficiency or pinch-)M*nny corner-cut­ ting, the Navy d»H*s the job cheapest: 
It costs $548 to train a sailor, com* pared with $9Xo for Rh* Army to train a soldier, 
The Navy also gets by with one in­ structor for every 3 4 apprentice sea­ 

 men whereas the Army says it needs one instructor for each 18 navies, 
On these figures alone — short time, low costs, high ratio of recruits to instructors — the Navy UmjKs good to the all-civilian CBU. 
Un the other hand, experienced of­ ficers who are familiar with the re­ cruit-training process point out that the Navy probably gets about whut It pays for. 

Reputation 

Navy recruit training has a service reputation for lax discipline and per­ functory instruction 
Those very qualities were singled out by a congressional investigation iii 1973 as bearing directly on the 
Navy's explosive mutinies, race-riuts aud waves of sabotage wfille Adm 
Elmo H Zumwalt was chief of naval operations 

One evident premise of the CBG study is that four months is too long to devote to training. 
The study suggests this derives from the recently repealed ( 1975) 
Korean War congressional restriction on sending anyone overseas with less than four months training. (Now 
C ongress has set the lim it at 12 weeks, which its Budget Office be­ lieves is about right.) 
Pentagon sources, reluctant to contradict the powerful ( BO on re­ cord, sharply disagree. 

Iii their view, the 17 weeks average training for every serviceman repre­ sents an empirical figure which hap­ pens to coincide with the old con­ gressional m inim um . Whether it dot's so by chance or not, they add, four months is none loo long 
Attitude 
Recruit training, a-* seen by the military , is not just a lime for a man to learn certain skills but to acquire a soldier s attitude and, above all, lo internalize habits of discipline and sell-discipline, 
Experience shows that discipline, not so much as skill, is what dimin­ ished with curtailed initial training 

Tile Marines, with a 19-week train­ ing cycle on HO-lioui weeks, actually have more (and more intense) re­ cruit training than any other service. 
(The Air Force has 21 w eeks, but they are only 43 hours.) 

The object of the long, gruelling 
Murine tx Mil training is discipline and attrition of unsuitables. 

Bul a British marine or guardsman 
(lo whom Marines are often com ­ pared) or a Foreign Legionnaire has to put in a minimum of six months as a recruit. 
These six-month periods are ad­ m ittedly also em p irical but they represent the best judgment of some seasoned pros in the guards and in the legion, who may not exactly share the viewpoint and perceptions of bright economists and statisticians. 

Probably the fundamental differ­ ence between the civilian efficiency experts and tin* soldiers comes down to the fact that the CBG with lls sit- derules and dollar sig n s, view s training and its expenditures us a loss. white the regular soldier sees training — especially recruit training 
— as a capital investment with pro­ portional longterm returns

Carter were good enough to c reate and strengthen this nation, we can justi­ fiably hope that they will again make the Pledge of Allegiance a moving ceremony for all Americans. 
Arthur L. Cox 
Gas shortage facts are needed 

Sir. We, the public, are sick and tired of reading and listening about the oil and gas shortage in our country and. of course, the price which we have had to pay. 

We have read and heard about breaking up the oil com p anies. 
Wouldn’t it be to this country’s and its 
People’s advantage if our federal go­ vernment would nationalize the leasing of land and its drilling, including offshore drilling and sell to the oil companies all the new discoveries iii oil and gas? 
Also, for regulation purposes, take over the already jiroductng oil and gas but sell this to the oil companies at no cost to them? 
Mexico, in the mid-2os nationalized the oil industry lock, stock and barrel. 
Most people said they wouldn't make it. They have made it and improving it daily. It’s about time the public should know whether we have a shortage or not. Who knows, we might have an abundance over night. 
A.J. Richards 

Carter sounds uncertain trum pet 

W A SH IN G T O N - P r e s id e n t 
Carter g a ve the country the old 
Dutch Uncle treatm ent in his first fireside talk. 

All real cosy, quiet and family like— but lie has a problem with this gentle, folksy approach to the energy crisis. 

His problem is that he has been say­ ing ever since he came into national jxditics that the American people are good and generous, and merely need leaders as good and generous as themselves. 

There is nothing in their response to the energy shortage to support this romantic \ jew. 

It may be good polities, but it s bad history. 

Hard truth 

The hard truth is that we are the most recklessly wasteful people in tin* world, that, by his own estimate, we are actually wasting more fuel than we import from other countries. 

Our record since the oil embargo of 
1973 is neither good nor generous, but is a national disgrace. 

This is not one of those big obscure and complicated questions — like what to do about cruise missiles or Backfire bombers — that ordinary folk can’t quite figure out. 

It’s as simple as turning down the thermostat to 85 and sticking to the speed limit. 

But for all the pleadings and warn­ ings of the past three years, the con­ sumption of fuel has kept going up until we are now relying on foreign sources for about 49 per cent of our supplies. 

New approach 

The stage was set for a realistic new approach to this mounting problem. 
The President was making his first major policy speech since the inau­ guration. 

The country has been in the deep­ freeze for almost a month, but he didn’t focus on the emergency. 
Ile ranged over a wide field of sub­ jects, many of them familiar from his old campaign speeches, and called for a “ spirit of cooperation and mutual effort” to help him develop “ predicta­ ble, long-range programs that we can 
Im* sure we can afford and that we know will work.’’ 

What is at issue here is Carter’s as­ sumption that the American people will respond to his modest appeals. 

He asked the people for “dedication 
— perhaps even for sacrifice.” 

No ringing call 

I bis is scarcely a ringing call for action equal to the problem, and by the time he produces his own energy pro­ gram on April 29. the chances are that the memories of the hard winter will have faded and the Congress will be less willing to vote an effective energy policy than it is today. 
N evertheless, Carter has his own sense of timing and his own personal approach to government. 
Roosevelt took ad vantage of the economic crisis of 1933 to rush through a program iii “ the first PMI da>s.” on the theory that his authority would slip with the jiassage of tune. 
Lyndon Johnson did the same iii the immediate* months after the assassin­ ation of President Kennedy. 

Carter obviously has a different phi­ losophy. 

He is playing down Ins own authuri- 

“There is no way that I, or anybody else*, can solve our energy problems if you are not willing to help, ’ he said. 
He is seeking voluntary cooperation, and avoiding mandatory controls, and this seems to he his approach ill other fields as well. 

The question 

The question is whether quiet ex­ hortation will work. 
As soon as he departs from general principles and calla for specific action, he runs into opposition. 
In the energy field, there is far from general agreement that substantial savings eau he made without hurting the economy and lowering the nation’s standard of bv mg 

Iii its “ Energy to the \e a r 1985.” report, for example, the Chase Man­ hattan Bank questions Carter’s view that we are wasting more energy than we import 

"The great hulk of the energy is utilized for essential purposes," it says 
—as much as two thirds is for bust- ness-relaled reasons. 
And most of the rem aining third serves essentia! private needs 

Bv lite time Hie spring comes and 
< arter presents his energy bill, we will 
Im1 hearing much more of this theme. hut by then the administration hopes the new President s quiet appeals will have produced a new spirit of eooja-r- at ion and conservation 

 lf they do, it wilt be Ute hapjuest development since two-bit gas

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Feb 5 1977 
D ecrease in unem ploym ent called deceptive 

WASHINGTON (AP) — The nation’s unemployment rate fell to an eight- month low of 7.J per cent in January, but the White House said Friday the figures are deceptive and the cold weather probably w ill push the rate up again this month. 

One Labor Department official said the decline in January unemployment could be partly caused by people giv­ ing up the search for work because of the cold w e a th e r, e s p e c ia lly in agricultural areas where the cold has destroyed entire crops. 

The J a n u a ry u n em p lo y m e n t r a te was down a full half of a percentage point from the December rate of 7.8 per cent and equaled the post-reces­ sion low of last May. By comparison, the recession’s high was 9 per cent in 
May 1975. 

The J a n u a ry d ec lin e in u n e m ­ ployment was widespread throughout all job c a te g o rie s , e s p e c ia lly for adults. 
But White House P ress S ecretary 
Judy Powell said that while President 
Carter is pleased by the development. 

 his "pleasure is tinged with a heavy degree of caution. 
"The economy is not improving an­ ywhere near as fast as these figures would indicate,” Powell said. He ad ­ ded that unemployment probably will rise in February as the effects of the 

 cold w eath er and the n a t u r a l g a s shortage make themselves felt. 
Almost all of the decline in u n e m ­ ployment was due to a big drop in the nujnber of workers in the labor force, which officials were unable to fully explain. 

Mecca for all who love birds 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Feb 5 1977 
 iM W Itt 

The upper deck of a small boat off Blackjack Peninsula on the Gulf Coast of Texas is an unexpected place to meet an 
Australian. 
The boat was moving up the Inter­ coastal Waterway. 
What a beautiful scene it was! 
These are the scatters of the sea — mile after mile of thick, matted swamp g rass, dotted with saltw ater ponds, inlets and winding channels that the bright afternoon sun was turning to silver. 
Everyw here you looked were the birds — gulls, terns, cranes, herons, pelicans, cormorants, geese — and a dozen varieties of ducks. 
And over the long, long stretches of brown swamp grass, the biggest hawks you ever saw sailed — and looked —in their unending fight against sta rv a ­ tion. 
It is a conservative estimate that in that 4-hour boat trip, those aboard spotted or had pointed out to them more than 75 species of birds. 
That was not too unusual. It has been reported that the longest list of birds ever tallied in the U.S. in one day was found in this area — 2o4 species. 
List of birds 
The Australian, too, had his list of birds he was checking off. 
But what he said when Bonnie and I introduced ourselves to him put the purpose of the boat trip in focus. 
“ You know,” he said, “ for those of us around the world who love birds — this is Mecca.” 
It is “ Mecca” for one reason. 
T h is is the winter home of the 
Whooping Cranes. 
The fight — now going on for more than 25 years — to save the noblest of all waterfowl from extinction has cap­ tured the imagination of people every­ where. 
The Australian was John Mildren from Ballarat, in the state of Victoria. 
Mildren is a teacher at Ballarat Col­ lege for Advanced Education. He is now at Texas A&M studying commun­ ity education methods. 
But the first chance he got — here he came to the area of the Aransas N a­ tional W ildlife R efu ge to see the whoopers. 
Boat trip 
The Sea Gun R esort Hotel — on 
Highway 35 where Aransas Bay and 
Copano Bay join — runs a boat trip 
Wednesday through Sunday afternoons to see the whooping cranes. 
The boat is the “ Whooping Crane.” 

Its skipper for the past 14 years has been Capt. Brownie Brown — equally skilled in boating, bird-spotting and colorful microphone language. 
Bonnie and I were on board Friday afternoon of last week. 
Our visit to the whooping cranes was 

 a “ double dip.” We followed the boat trip with a visit to the refuge Saturday. 
What a combination! 
We had a fine break at the refuge. 
Glen Smart, coordinator of endangered species research for U. S. Fish and 
Wildlife Service, was there. He talked to us about the long fight to save the whoopers. 
As recently as 1954 there were only 
23 whoopers alive. 
Today there are 99. 
The largest group is the B9 on the refuge and nearby. Of these, 12 were hatched last summer. 
Then there are six in the wild with the greater sandhill cranes that nest in 
Idaho and winter in New Mexico. This is an unusual experiment designed to get the whooping cranes spread out so they will be less vulnerable to a disas­ ter that might strike one area. All those that winter at Aransas nest at 
Wood Buffalo National Park in the far north of Canada and the flock migrates on the same route. 
“ There usually are two eggs in the whooping crane nest. But they are not laid at the sam e time and this usually m eans that only one of the eg g s is hatched,” Smart said. 
"So we have taken one egg from a num ber of n ests and put them in 

Because there are so many, the gull often is considered a commonplace sort of bird. But what can surpass the 

 beauty of gulls silhouetted against the wispy clouds of a blue Texas sky? The boat is headed for the marshy 

 meadows of the sea where live the birds no once considers commonplace — the whooping cranes. 

 sandhill crane nests in Idaho In 1975, four birds were hatched. But one dis­ appeared and we don’t know why 
“ This year four were again hatched from 14 eggs. But on the migration south one was killed when hi* flew into a fence. 
"We do not believe tin* whoopers will cross-breed with the sandhills but that 

 is a possibility. Whoopers start nesting when they are about five years old A couple m ates for life and both male and female sit on the eggs.” 
There are 24 whooping cran es i i i captivity — again another way to keep the species alive if d isaster struck those in the wild. 
The P atuxent W ildlife R esearch 
Experts w atching S.A. Zoo 

“ For those of us around the world 

 who love birds — this is M ecca.” 
So says Australian John Mildren 

 on his visit to the Texas G u lf 
Coast country where the whoop­ ing cranes winter. 

The eyes of whooping crane experts are on the San Antonio zoo. 
Will Crip and Ektu live happily — and affectionately — ever after? When nesting season ends will there be some baby whoopers brightening their San 
Antonio home? 
A determined effort is being made to raise whoopers in captivity. 
If a disaster wiped out the whoopers in the wild, zoo cranes could save the species from extinction. 
Crip is a tough old-timer. He was found with a broken wing at the Aran­ sas refuge in October 1949 

He and Josephine were parents of several whoopers at the New Orleans zoo. After Josephine died, ( rip and 
Rosie were mated here at the San 
Antonio zoo. One of their offspring. 
Tex, born iii 19H7, is at the Interna­ tional Crane Foundation at Baraboo, 
Wis. 
Rosie died in 1971 and now Ektu has been transferred to San Antonio from the Patuxent research center. 
Ektu has had two trial marriages. 
Neither worked. Ektu whipped and dominated both of her grooms and no romance followed. 

"But when she started acting tough with (’rip, he really showed her who was boss,” Louis Iii Sabato, head of the zoo, reports. 

“ All seems to be working well. We believe such things as a special diet and lengthened daylight hours may induce Ektu to lay more than the two eggs usually found in a whooper nest 
We believe it may be possible for her to lay as many as nine eggs." 
No one knows how old ( rip is. He was an adult when he was found almost 
3o years ago. 

Center in Maryland has 19. Then* is a pair at the San Antonio zoo and another pair at the International Crane Trust at 
Baraboo, Wis. This is a private opera­ tion set up by a young man who got so interested that he wrote his Phi) thesis on cranes The New Orleans zoo has one whooper 
The Aransas refuge has a tall obser­ vation tower looking out on San An tonio Bay and nearby marshy areas. It is designed to give refuge visitors a look at the whooper family that claims this area. 
Whooper families stake an area of marsh and sea as their home territory. 
No other whoopers are allowed to trespass. Strangely they allow any other waterfowl or bird to (‘liter freeR 
We were unable to spot any whoopers from the tower. But what wonderful sightings we had from the boat trip 

Counting 

We counted whoopers only on the outbound boat trip. And as we reached our most distant point, just offshore

Antique stove 

I have a stove which I think may be a collector’s item. This stove came from the estate of a Span- ish-Amerlcan War veteran who died many years ago.lf you could give me information on how old it might be, it would he very much appreciated. 
I would also like information on what it may have been used for and names of possible buyers or experts on old stoves. 
I think the stove, which is about 25 inches high, must have been used for a prairie schooner and intended to burn coal. 
A covered wagon pulled by a pair of oxen is embossed on the door. The name above the wagon and oxen is "Buddy.” 
“ Fair Ave. Tin Shop, Benton Harbor, Mich No. 
‘JOO” is marked on the stove. 
Can you put me in contact with someone who knows something about this stove? 
S. II 

The San Antonio Mu­ seum Assn. and the Witte 
Memorial Museum could provide you with the in­ formation you need 

A spokesman from the association said you could take a picture of 
(he stove and send it to them. They also would 

 like a description of the stove. 
Send the picture and the description to Mrs. 
Cecilia Steinfeldt, 38o1 
Broadway, San Antonio 
782o9. 
They will contact you as soon as they have stu­ died the material you send them. 

Fashion m odel 
How does one go about becoming a fashion model for any of the local department stoVcs^ 
I am married, have three children and no previous modeling experience. 
However, I think it would be very interesting and I would like to know what I must do to qualify or who 
I might contact to get any additional information 
Thank you for any help 
A reader 
You can contact indivi­ dual department stores you would be interested in modeling for and work for them on a free-lance basis. 
But the going won t be easy if you have no ex­ perience or connections in the modeling business. lf you are seriously considering modeling on a part or full-time basis, 
>ou should take a modeling course and then sign on with a local agency. 
Ben Shaw Modeling 
Studio offers modeling courses. The complete course will cost about 
$375. lf \ou have had some training, they have 

 a refresher course for 
$2o(1 
The lessons are pri­ vate. Once you have been accepted into the modeling program and have completed the course, you will be listed as a registered model with their agency. 

The agency will get you bookings in San Antonio. 
The bookings will include fashion shows, photog­ raphy sessions, promo­ tions and the like. 
For more information on registering for a modeling course, call 
Ben Shaw Modeling Stu­ dio at 223 8231. The studio is at 813 Brooklyn Vve.

Druggist m onitor role vital 

I have heard from several druggists who were upset concerning my response to a writer who asked about the continued use of a certain drug. The writer noted that her pharmacist questioned her about continued use of the medication over along period of time, and she asked me what she should do. 
My response was that, her physician was the best judge of the matter, because as her doctor, he is the one best qualified to balance any potential risks against her specific needs. 

This response was, of course, not intended to imply that the lady’s druggist was wrong in sug­ gesting a review of the drug therapy. In fact, In an earlier column I strongly emphasized the vital role p h a rm a c ists have a l­ l a y s played in this matter. 
Any long-range medi cation use m ust be re ­ viewed from tim e to time to note any possible adverse effects. But, as I suggested, the attending physician is the one to do the monitoring and, of course, m ake the d e ­ cision based on the pa­ tients’ needs. 
Well, all this got me in the soup with some of my p h a rm a c ist col­ leagues. It is important that the pharm acist in the above case did ques­ tion the prolonged use of the drug, as it is with any potentially hazardous drugs, hi fact, many pharmacists will contact a physician about such continued use. 
The physician may not always be aware of it. 
Teamwork is necessary. So I stand by my previous comments, even though I regret any m isunder­ standing that may have been created. 

Bulk diet 

Dear Dr Thosteson: Can a person on a low-calorie diet get constipated? I’ve been trying to lose weight, but I’ve noticed a change in my bowel habits, with a mild constipation Please comment. — Mrs. O W. 
It’s not how much you eat as what you are eating. 
Bulk is important, as you know, in promoting bowel activity. But a low-calorie diet doesn’t have to be one that sacrifices bulk, unless it’s one of those horrible liquid weight loss programs 
Most reducing diets emphasize vegetables and such, which contain much cellulose. Cellulose is a good bulk producer. 
Other foods are absorbed chiefly in the lower intestines, where they help keep the bowels active. 
Sugar is one, and eliminating that might account for some bowel changes. I’m not recommending that you start eating sugar, however — a bit of pruiw juice might be all you need. There are a couple of sensible weight loss diets in my booklet, "Lost 
Secrets of Reducing.” Readers can get a copy by sending 35 cents and a stam ped, self-addressed envelope to care of this newspaper. 

Bed wetting can be a frustrating problem but it can be controlled 

To learn how, write to Dr Thosteson in care of this newspaper, for a 

 copy pf his booklet, "Bed Wetting: Ways to Stop It." Enclose a long, self addressed, stomped envelope and 25 cents 

By George ^ 
Thosteson, M.D.

Volunteer teacher 

Action-Express would he glad to pass this in­ formation on.

Antonie Literacy C ouneil at ‘223-4111.

38 centers, many of which offer help in preparing for G E D tests. 

( lasses are also offered lor (hose learning Eng­ lish as a second language and adult basic education in the elementary grades and pre-G.E.II, studies 

Mildew 
A couple of weeks ago, you had in your column a 
"recipe ’ for a solution for getting mildew off houses. 
I didn’t think I would need it then, but I do now. 
Could you reprint it for me? Thank vou very much 
I*. F. 

Alamo 
Paint and 
Wallpaper, 711 (ulebra 
Ave., 734-31o1, recoin mended Jomax, a con centrated solution that comes in three forms. 
There is exterior wood and paint, interior tile and paint and stone blick and stucco. It is a new 
Item and one quart costs 
St S3. 
The concentrate is 

 mixed with water and household bleach and then applied to the mil dewed area Scrubbing is necessary only when the mildew is severe. 

You can also use tri sodium phosphate. It is a powder which can be mixed with waler and/or bleach to remove mil- j dew.

Your Birthday Sunday: 
So many and so varied are the paths of probability which open before you that no estimate is possi­ ble One thing is certain you w ill wind up in places not planned, doing things beyond present skills or intentions, in company you don’t yet know Rela­ tionships are happy. 
Today’s natives work best in isolation with m ater­ ials or topics that would be upset by workaday congestion. Those born this year are ro m an ­ ticists, m ystics, s u p e r­ salesmen for intangibles. 

 a Nifty (M ores n April lf) 
Take initiative to squore oH ar counts. cot in t who* iv owed you, redeem obligations 
Cultivate new acquaintances 
Pays on a wood word to Did friend*..

Stay within your nudger

• ipect them to pay your tads

Parties agree in weeds issue 

By DAVID HENDRICKS 
City 
M gr. 
Tom 
H u e b n e r a g re e d w ith 
Com m unities Organized for 
P u b lic 
S e rv ice m em b ers F riday night th a t a b e tte r c le a n u p procedure is needed for weedy vacant lots. 

Several hundred COPS m e m b e r s from the 
Edgewood area met with the new city m anager at 
St. G a b r ie l’s C atholic 
Church hall to discuss ways to clean up vacant lots in the city. 
Huebner said he would s u p p o rt a p ro p o sal to give the city’s first a t ­ tention to weedy vacant lots n e a r c h u rc h e s , schools and playgrounds. 
Time frame 
He also said he favored a 28-day tim e fram e for the city to ta k e action after notifying negligent lot owners to clean away weeds or debris. 
If a fte r th re e w eeks, the ow ner has failed to co m p ly w ith city and m unicipal court orders, the city would hire crews t«> clean the lots, if money is available. 
However, Huebner told 
COPS m em bers the c u r­ rent city program is not w ell-staffe d no r well- funded. 
“ I would Uke an effec­ tive program , not a token p ro g ra m w hich e x ists 

 now,” the city m anager said 

Meeting the 
28-day tim e p ro g ra m w ill d e ­ pend also on the volume of weedy lot com plaints the city receives. 

The new steps are part of a p ro p o sal w hich would c la rify the city procedure in dealing with vacant lots and strength­ en the city o rd in a n c e ’s enforcement 

City C ouncil will r e ­ ceive a briefing on the proposal T hursday, and m a n y of th e 
COPS m em b ers at the F rid ay m eetin g indicated they would attend the council session in support of the proposal 

S e v era l 
CO PS m e m b e rs told H uebner the u n k ep t lots a ttr a c t junk and trash and help breed snakes, ra ts and cockroaches. 

Crime sites 

C rim es often occur in o v erg ro w n v a c a n t lots also, COPS m e m b e r s said. 

Huebner turned dow n a 
COPS requevSt to arrange a m eeting between City 
C ouncil, m u n ic ip a l judges and COPS to dis­ cuss the problem. 

COPS m e m b e r 
R i ­ 

 chard C ovarrubia said city officials should exert p ressure on m unicipal jud ges to levy h eavier fin es on n e g lig e n t lot owners. 

Covarrubia said m ost fines now are much less than the cost of cleaning the lots. 
Arrange 

H uebner said COPS should arrange the m eet­ ing, adding, “ lf you come and ask City Council to set up such a m eeting, then ITI probably say I think if s a good idea.’’ 
Also attending the Fri­ day m eetin g as an ob-, server only was Council­ man Al Rohde.

Express-News Want Ads 225-1666 

By VK KIE DAVIDSON 
Tourism from Mexico to the United States isn’t what it was before the devaluation of the peso. 
But, it’s picking up. 
“ The atmosphere bas improved. A lot of people are working at it.” Ri­ chard Blom, deputy dir­ ector of the U.S. Office of 
Tourism in Mexico City, said Friday night. 
The improvement can be attributed to con fi­ dence in the new govern­ ment, according to Hugh 
R odriguez, with R odri­ guez 
V iajes 
(tra v el agency) in Mexico City. 
The govern m en t changed w hen Jose Lopez 
P ortillo becam e p r e si­ dent of M exico in D e­ cember. 
Pick up 
Rodriguez said by the end of this year Mexican travel in the U.S. should pick up significantly.

R odriguez and Blom are in San A ntonio as part of a familiarization tour of T exas and Lo­ uisiana for more than 3o 
Mexican travel agents. 
The agents arrived in 
San Antonio Friday and will stay through Sunday. 
T hey are a lso touring 
Houston, Galveston and 
New Orleans. 
The joint tour — “C^r-- osel de la Alegria a Tex­ as y L o u isia n a ” — is sponsored by the U .S. 
Travel S ervice, A m eri­ can A irlin e s, H oliday 
In n s and C ontinental 
Trailways. 

Involved 
The San Antonio Con­ vention and V isito r ’s 
Bureau is also involved. 
Blom said the devalua­ tion of the peso — which began in Septem ber — has caused a 27 per cent drop in the num ber of tou rists com in g to the 
U.S. from Mexico.

Police seeking jewelry thieves 

P o lic e F rid ay w ere searching for two bandits who escaped with some 
$3o,ooo worth of diamond rin g s from a jew elry store. 
Taken in the robbery were 79 rings with an estim a ted valu e from 
$125 to $1,2oo. a $5oo m en ’s w atch and $5o from the cash register of 
La Moy’s Jewelry Store, 
734 S. W. W. White Road. 
The robbery occurred after Mrs. Shirley Per­ kins. daughter of firm owner J. J. La Moy, took a tray of the rings from a display counter to show to the two bandits, who w ere p osing as customers Thursday, po­ lice reported. 
O fficers Friday were also in v estig a tin g the burglary of some $11,ooo worth of silver service from the home of a pro­ minent businessman. 
Robert M. Luby, 66, told officers intruders apparently entered the hom e at 214 Oakhurst 
Place while he and his w ife were asleep, 
Luby owns the cafeter­ ia chain and is board chairman of Main Bank and Trust Co.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday Feb 5 1977 
B ird e rs w hoop it up on G u lf Coast 

Continued from Page IB 

 from the refuge’s Mustang Lake, ( apt 
Brown shouted: 
"Look! Look! There in the grass right at the end of the point! Two more whoopers!" 
Then he shouted even louder. 
"That makes 31 whoopers — 7 of them young birds!" 
Bonnie and I got an added break on this trip. ( apt. Brown’s 14 years on this run have given him unmatched knowledge of the birds. But this time he shared his microphone with John 
Rowlett. 
Houston has an travel agency — 
Victor Em anuel Nature Tours. Its clients come from across the nation. 
One of its groups was aboard today. 
Rowlett, one of the two owners, is a former president of the Texas Ornith­ ological Society. 
An unspoken drama made the trip mort' exciting. All the way down from 
San Antonio, tilt' car radio told of the terrible blizzard hitting the North and 
East. 
But here we were on the boat with some men in short-sleeved shirts and one or two women in halter top outfits 
Corpus Christi that afternoon broke an all-time Jan. 2H record. It was 83 
The first couple we approached about "back hom e" weather was 
Charles and Vera Sw alist rom of Fort 
Dodge, Iowa. 
"We called home this morning." he said. "It was ‘JU below — a 35-mile wind and a chill factor of 5(1 below. I was going to fly home for a big farm machinery exhibit but I’ve decided not to go." 
A 14-inch snow was falling when a couple from Hustings, Mich., headed south — on top of a lot of earlier snow. 
Weather 
There were two couples from Ro­ chester, Minn. — "we called home and the 11 IO! I forecast for today was ll below." 
There were three couples from Ver­ mont — one with a house looking out on 
Lake Champlain — "no need to call about tin* weather there." A Chicago couple reported the chill factor there was t)2 below —"all our schools are closed in Follansbee, VV. Va." — and even two people from Florida told of tin' freeze there. 
As we pulled out from the Sea Gun dock to start our trip and the propeller churned the water, the gulls took to the air right behind us 

The gull may be a commonplace bird 
— but is there anything to match the grace of a gull sailing motionless in the wind? 
Maybe the best way to give you a lit th* flavor of this wonderful trip is a sort of disjointed quoting of (’apt. 
Brown and Rowlett on the microphone 
— punctuated by the shouts of the ex­ pert birders on both of the boats decks. 
"These are laughing gulls 
— there’s an unusual one — his head is all black — look close-in at IO o’clock 
(all directions are given by tin' clock’s face) — it s a Bonaparte gull — almost solid white — off to the left bobbing there on water — it’s a golden eye — most ducks feed on salt water at this time of year — even those that go inland to fresh water to nest — that beautiful little white bird is a Forster’s tern — watch that one cut loose as lie dives . . . 
Crab traps 

"Look at all those crab traps bobbing in the water — lots of blue crabs here — quick — coming toward the boat at 5 o’clock — it’s a ring-billed gull — Chin­ ese use them for fishing 
— put a collar round their neck so they can't swallow the fish they catch — here comes a herring gull — biggest gull on this coats — 
“ Talk about something pretty — look at all those birds covering every inch of that sandbar — that big white cluster is pele­ va ns — the black cluster stringing out from this — cormorants — 
“ Hurry -— at 2 o’clock 
— see that blanket of ducks — what a mixture 
— pintails — gadwalls — widgeons — there's a shoveler . . . 
We had been following a marked channel across tin' bay and now iii front of us was a big marker with a red “ 13" on it. We cut sharp left and were iii the Intercoastal W ater­ way — headed alongside the great marshes where the whoopers are. Sud- 

 ln tim e cam e that fin a l shout o f Copt. Brown — as his w hooper count rea ch ed 31 and we hea d ed fo r hom e 

 shouted: 

“ There they are — there they are — see those two white slashes in the water right near the shoreline 
—they’re our first whoopers. For the purpose of the count, that’s two." 

Spotting other waterfowl continued 
— and sailing above the tangled marsh grass of Rattlesnake Island was a big marsh hawk. A small sparrow hawk trailed him. Then came an unusual find, a white-tailed hawk found in the 
U.S. only in South Texas and Arizona. 
Soon a great flight of blue Canada geese settled on the water — three 

 brown pelicans, now becoming rare, were in flight. 

But the big story was the whoopers and ( apt. Brown kept the microphone popping: 
Grass 

"Look over there in the grass — there’s three whoopers — the one with the slightly reddish color is one of this year’s crop.” 

Then tilt1 captain almost shouted: 

“ Look way over yonder toward that tree line — on the far side of the lake — 

 there are six whoopers — watch that one jump and flash his wings — there he goes again!” 

All the whoopers we saw were dis­ tant but near enough that the outline of the white birds could be seen clearly — particularly through binoculars — and the profile was unmistakeable. 

The count kept mounting — some­ times three — usually a pair — some­ times a lone bird — neck stretched high out of thevgrass. 

Then came the highlight of the day for Bonnie and me. 

A winding inlet came into the bay at our left. 

In front of its mouth was a mass of great blue herons. Behind them were 

2o or 3o of those wonderful white peli­ cans. And mixed in with them was an almost equal number of roseate spoonbills! 

In time came that final shout of 
(apt. Brown — as his whooper count 
-cached 31 and we headed for home. 

How much I would like to tell you about our next day on the refuge — the trees at Dagger Point — the clumps of oak and the great fields of brown sage 
— ducks noisily winging up from sparkling little ponds. And we must have seen little herds of deer a dozen times. 
But the thing we will remember most — 
Turning a corner in that little Loop 
Road and out in front of us walking majestically down the road — eight big. bronze w ild turkeys.

Remember when the house at the corner of Fredericksburg and Wurzbach Roads was “way out in the country” ? 

W hen the Wolff fa m ily built the 
G erm an-inspired turn-of-the-century 
Texas home and raised their children across the street from their Wolff's Inn restaurant? 

And later when Mr. and Mrs. John 
McAlpine lived there in retire m e n t, nam ing the house W hite Hall after their ranch near Navasota? 

And when the McAlpine’s daughter and son-in-law, the Earl F. Coopers, lived down the road in the old Jo e 
Frost home on a w orking ranch the 
Coopers called Lively Oaks? 

Mrs. Cooper rem em bers vividly the 
"g ran d tim es" the close-knit family had entertaining in those grand old homes for her friends and friends of the Cooper children—Claude and Earl 
Faye, now Mrs. Huard Eldridge. 

(Since then, the site has been used as a plant em porium.) 

But she hasn't seen the house since it has been transformed into Ichabod’s restaurant. 

" M o th e r’s house had ham m ocks, hanging baskets and flowers blooming everywhere," says Mrs. Cooper who helped her mother furnish the home with Victorian antiques. 
"The house was all open with high.
