 high ceilings and a kitchen three times as big as the one I have now ." 
I think Mrs. Cooper, and all former 

 residents of the area, will be pleased with the rem odeling that has taken place. 
The wide porches have been glassed in and ceiling fans and big rattan chairs added to give it the airy feeling 
Mrs. Cooper rem em bers. 
Most of the furnishings, however, are from antique shops around Texas; the outstanding piece is a signed Tiffany grandfather clock. 

 unique— and people would rem em ber it. 
Entrees, including some com bina­ tions of seafood, beef and poultry, range in price from $4.75 to $s 5o 
Although salads and side dishes such as potatoes are extra, the entrees are served with a tray of fresh vegetables 
(carrot and celery sticks, broccoli and cauliflower Burettes, cherry tomatoes, mushrooms) with a dip and a basket of both dark and light rolls 

A,, 

 rills tim e of year. a graceful fire­ place adds warmth. 

The look is typical of his restaurants, sayd Ichabod’s, Inc., President Cril 
Payne of Dallas. 

The sm all chain with locations in 
D allas and New O rleans seeks out existing properties for development and selected Northwest San Antonio ba­ its growth potential. 

The restaurant’s nam e was picked in a brainstorm ing session because it is 

 p p e liz e rs 

Appetizers available at an additional price include two seafood cocktails, two soups and a romaine salad 
I tasted four things I thought were excellent— the vegetable tray, the ro­ maine salad. Steak Oscar (tenderloin topped with H ollandaise sauce and king crabmeat with mushrooms and a hint of wine sauce) and the New J e r ­ sey-type baked cheesecake 
Both the Shrimp Tem pura and the shrim p in the cocktail I tasted were som ew hat tough. The F ren ch onion soup was not outstanding but was pre­ sented attractiv ely " b a k e d ” with a crouton and cheese on top 
The Cajun Seafood Gumbo was a complete disappointment and had to be sent back. 

Ichabod’s is open from 5:3(1 to 1o:3(1 p.m. Monday through Thursday and until ll p.m. Friday though Sunday. 
The restaurant does not take reser­ v atio n s but h a s a b a r a re a for waiting—and a little nostalgic conver­ sation.

PHOTOS BY CHARLES BARKSDALE 

DARLENE A S BRIDESM AID 
...sheer, sum m er prints g iv e airy look 
Priscilla shows 'something new’ 

IU EVK LYNN SAH YER 

The bridal fashion designer known around the world as 
Priscilla of Boston withstood the ice and snow of Cleveland with its Iii below t e m p e r a ­ ture. 
Then, she came to San An­ tonio and hurt her leg lump­ ing over a mud puddle. 
S h o rt s before she co m m en te d at her wedding show for 
F r o s t’s. 
Priscilla Kidder was resting on a couch in the Bridal Salon and put­ ting hot p ac k s on h e r ankle. Her discomfort had no effect on the style show. 
In her interview, 
Priscilla said 
I he biggest news iii wedding dresses is the variation of fabric being used. 
“ We have a new s u m m e r satin m a d e of Qiana that is lighter than silk organdy. It’s like a leath er.’’ 

PRISCILLA OF BOSTON 

“ Org andy and English net used to he the m a in s u m m e r fa bric s, but now w e're using Qiana*, chiffon and so m e jersey. Cotton h a s n ’t re a r e d its head for a long ti m e , but it s 

 coming back. 
“ In the early I st h century, the ladies used to w e a r cotton for a f­ 

 ternoon g a r d e n parties. Cotton to­ d ay is u n r e a c h a b l e in th e lo w er price range. The labor picture has m a d e it expensive.” 
Some of the 1977 wedding gowns have an 18th cen tury look with their lowered, s q u are necklines and short sleeves. One of the biggest innova­ tio n s is in a new l e n g t h for th e w e d d in g vim I th a t e x t e n d s to th e calf 

T h i s new w a l k i n g - l e n g t h veil f ram e s the d re s s and floats. P ris­ cilla s m i l e d w r y ly . “ N a t u r a l l y , everybody will copy it. People say that it in flattering to be copied*, but it’s annoying. Today, i f s diffi­ cult for people to recognize q u a li­ ty.” 
The latest idea in bridesmaids* dresses is that they no longer have to be identical. 
P r isc illa c o m b i n e s v i b r a n t 

 shades of lime, shocking pink and lilac so that each attendant is iii a different color. It s an update on the form er “ rainbow ” wedding. 
Another variatio n is in styling. 
The d resse s m a y all be in the s a m e fabric, but have different necklines and body lines as well as different colors. 

Priscilla explains it in a practical man ner . 
“ A single style isn't becoming to everyone. Now, i f s possible to get the most becoming dress for each 
' a t t e n d a n t . T h e y will h a v e su ch choices as halter or asy m m e trica l n e c k l i n e s w ith a c c o m p a n y i n g s c a r v e s to be worn in th e m o s t flattering m a n n e r for each brid es­ maid. This will eliminate the c o m ­ plaint that a b ri d e s m a i d ’s dre ss can never be worn after the w e d d in g .” 
P riscilla g e s t u r e d to w a rd h er g o w n s a s s h e m e n t i o n e d s h e e r prints, such as the delicate green and white English fabric by Laura 

A s h l e y , a n d th e n e a r b y d o tt e d swiss, linens and voiles. She added. 
“ We do a lot of lettuce edging on the b r i d e s m a i d s ’ dresses. Sometim es, we add picture h a ts .” 
As she m used over brides she has dresse d for that m a r c h down the aisle. 
Priscilla mentioned 
Luci 
Johnson Nugent. 
“ I like Luei very much. She is a nice and a spirited girl. I cancelled my first trip to Europe to assist with he r wedding. T h e Johnsons never knew it. There s no accounting for the ti m e that went into 
Luci’s w ed ding .” 
With a smile, 
Priscilla added there w a s n ’t likely to be another 
W h i t e H o u s e w e d d i n g for s o m e time. “ Amy Carter won’t be m a r ­ ried while her father is p resid ent.” 
For our interview Priscilla was wearing a gray turtleneck knit top and a m a tchin g flannel skirt m a d e in F ra n c e with a hemline that was scalloped an d pleated. Most u n u ­ sual.

 rewarded. And when you punish me, m a k e sure the p u n i s h m e n t fits t h e crime. 
A b o v e all, g r u n t m e unconditional love. F o r if 
I know it is there, I w ill be able to give the sam e to my children — and they will Im* able to give it to theirs. 
D ear Ann L an d ers: 
Last May I m a r rie d a di­ vorced man . A few weeks a f t e r o u r m a r r i a g e he ha nd ed m e the wedding r in g his f i r s t wife h ad placed on bis finger and said, “ Do w h a t e v e r you want with this. It has no meaning to m e . ” 
I p u t t h e r i n g in m y jewelry box but whenever

I am 13, alm ost 11

FII be a freshman in high school and I want an act­ ing career. I do not ex­ pert to get paid much but will work almost all the time. —Jonathan 

W ell. Jo n ath an , that 

 sounds almost like a S i­ tuation Wanted Ad. How­ ever, you arc going about achieving your desire the right way by learning various aspects of your craft. Study drama, read books, perform as an ac­ tor aud singer whenever you can. U ltim ately, if yo u 're good and you really desire the career. you could wind up being very well paid.

T H E B IB L E 

No. 277. Daniel in the Lions' Den 

Because tho other princes and presidents had grown onvious of the manner in which Daniel served King Darius, they decided that they could only avenge themselves upon him by attacking his religion. Consequently, they persuaded King Darius to establish a royal statute forbidding the asking of any favor of god of man, with the lone exception of King Darius Anyone found guilty of violating this law was to be cast in the lions' den 
Daniel, of course, continued to pray to God three times each day Ho was immediately reported by the jealous officials Although King Darius tried to save Daniel, he could not violate the law, and 
Daniel was placed in the den of lions Darius returned to his palace and fasted, and he spent a sleepless night worrying about Daniel The next morning the king rushed to the lions' den and called to Daniel 
Daniel replied, My God hath sent hts angel, and hath shut the lions' mouths, that they have not hurt me forasmuch as before him innocency was found in me; and also beloro thee. O king, have I done no hurt 
So Daniel was taken up out of the don, and no manner of hurt was found upon him, because ho believed rn his God " (Daniel 6 22-23)

Pastors join TLC program 

Pastors from San An­ tonio and 
Austin will spend a week at Texas 
Lutheran 
College starting Tuesday as part of a program to develop closer relations between the congregations and the college community. 
Pastor Robert Thom­ son of Hope Lutheran 
Church in San Anotnio and the Rev. and Mrs. 
John 
Auer from 
St. 
Marlin Lutheran Church in Austin will participate in the program through 
Feb. Hi 
The pastors will stay in student apartments, visit selected classes, attend campus events and acti­ vities, eat with students in Riche Dining Hall and use the library resources for personal study pro­ jects. 
Funding for the pas- tors-in-residence pro­ gram comes from the 
Division of College and 
University Services of the American Lutheran 
Church. 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Feb 5 1977 
Page 
S C 
Rabbi Stahl assumes 
Beth-El pulpit Friday 

“ The Liberated Wailing Wall,” an evangelistic team of Jews for 
Jesus, will present a concert on Tuesday at St. John’s Lutheran Church, 
5o2 E. Nuevo St. and on Thursday in the Harlandale High School 
Auditorium, I I 4 E. Gerald Ave. Both concerts will start at 7:3o p.m. 
The group, comprised of six Jewish young people who have come to believe in Jesus, has released three albums and has performed extensively throughout the United States and in Israel. The public is invited to attend both concerts. 

Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl will he formally installed as senior rabbi of Temple 
Beth-El in liturgical ceremonies at 8 p.m. 
Friday at the synagogue. 
211 Belknap Place. 
Rabbi Emeritus David 
Jacobson, who retired last July after 38 N ears iii 
Beth-El’s pulpit, will conduct the ceremony of the ninth rabbi i i i the congregations 1o3-year history. 
A special liturgy pre­ pared for the event will be read by Rabbi Roy A. 
W alter, senior rabbi- elect of Temple Emanti 
El, Houston. 
Rabbi 
Samuel ll. 
Karff, senior rabbi of 
Temple 
Both 
Israel, 
Houston, will deliver the installation sermon 
Representatives of lo- 

CHURCH MEWS 

 cal civic and religious groups have been inv ited to vv it ness the ceremony us special guests of the 
Temple.

Rabbi Stahl's installa­ tion. Rabbi Herbert A 
Yoskowitz of Oongrega tion Brith Shalom Bt loire, will deliver tin 
Torah lesson on “ The 
Second 
Revolution” at 
1o:31) a in. Feb. 12

At 7:3o p.m. Sunday the Jewish Community 
Center, 1o3 VV. Rampart 
Drive, will present Dr. 
Harold Liebowitz, assis­ tant professor of oriental and African languages at the University of Texas at Austin. 
He will give a slide-il­ lustrated lecture on a summer excavation at a prehistoric site in Eas­ tern Lower Galilee. 
The public- is invited to attend at no charge. For more information, call the center at 344-3453. 

Six charged 
NICOSIA. Cyprus — 
The Cyprus government announced Friday it is charging six Greek Cy­ priots in connection with the murder of U.S. Am­ bassador 
Rodger 
P. 
Davies here almost three years ago. 

The safety of our citi­ zens in the streets is an issue of crucial impor­ tance to the city. 
Encouragement has come with the announce­ ment by Bill Holchak of the Metropolitan Crimin­ al Justice Council that violent crimes in San 
Antonio have decreased almost 28 per cent in the past year. 
W hile the televised news plays up every crime of violence with such dramatic intensity as to create the impres­ sion of danger lurking at every street corner, the fact is that San Antonio is becoming a safer city. 
Responsibility 
One of the major re­ sponsibilities of govern­ ment is to hold evil in check. It is to help to 

Bv 
Rev- 
___ 
Jiminy R. 
Pastor. 
First Baptist Church 

 protect its citizens from violence. 
The New Testament tells us in the thirteenth chapter of Romans that the officer of the state is an instrument of God for this purpose. 
In light of the im ­ proved record of safety in the center city, it is un­ believable that the City 
Council has allowed

Texas skies clear 

ASSOCIATED FUESS 

Fair temperatures and clear skies prevailed over most of Texas Friday as part of a welcome warming trend that settled over the state, but cooler temper­ atures were expected during the weekend. 
Only the extreme east and southeast portions of 
Texas reported cloudy skies. The blunket of low clouds and patchy big extended east of a line from 
Texarkana to Longview lo Houston and was moving slowly eastward out of the state. 
Winds across the state were light and norlhly to northwesterly spreading dry air over Texas and helping clear the skies. 
Temperatures early in the afternoon ranged from 
32 in El Paso and Wichita Falls to the mid 8os in 
Dele Rio. Waco and portions of the Lower Coast. 
The National Weather Service said cooler tem­ peratures will prevail Saturday under partly cloudy skies.

M E X IC O 

NEW LIFE CENTER 
POSITIVE THINKING AT ITS BEST 
ADUll SUNDAY SCHOOl 
1o:oo A.M. 
CHURCH SnVICi 
11:oo A.M. 

S e r m o n Su b ject 
“ WHERE IS YOUR STRENGTH” 
W r**t8 f» — 
Dm Md Arr KwmHi, J.O. Md Pol Honey 
KO GER C X IC U T IV i CIN TER 
(babcock A Loop 41o) 
4243 Pierrot Or. w b u t n o v m 
Suit* 2SO 

 funding to lapse which supported foot patrols in downtown San Antonio. 
The funding came from the federal revenue shar­ ing funds. That source ran out Dee. 31. 
Negligence 
Patrolm en in the 
Houston Street and Ala­ mo Plaza area dropped from 3o to 2o. It may be a case of crim inal negli­ gence on the part of city leaders to allow such a process to go unnoticed. 
Police Chief E . E. 
Peters has been utilizing his officers in overtime for some of these patrols because the funding was temporary. 
It is now evident tile prevention of crime in 
Hie streets is greatly as­ sisted by highly visible law enforcement pre­ sence. Funding should lie found for the provision til such law enforcement in the center city as a high priority matter. 
Risen 
Suburban crim e has risen while center city crime has dropped 
That fact has not yet soaked through in the public mind. 
It is important both for the tourists who visit our lovely city and for the ci­ tizens that downtown streets be sale. 
Arguments develop as to whether the presence of policemen should be assured before housing increases and the popu­ lation rises or whether it should wait until a higher number of people have chosen to live downtown. 
It is an argument of which comes first, the chicken or the egg. 
Threatened 
People will choose to 
Iiv4* in the center city witll its cultural, re li­ gious and business re­ sources along the beauti­ ful San Antonio river only when safety is assured. 
That process has been developing and now is being threatened by inat­ tention. 
The basic answer to crime problems and vio­ lence iii the streets lies in the change of the inner heart and intention of persons. That process is beyond the reach of force. 
Policemen cannot be the real answers to crime. However, the ne­ cessity to hold crime and violence in check to the greatest degree possible in a free society is abso­ lutely essential. 

Citizens have to pay the bills for doing it, but the price we pay for not doing it is much higher than the taxes. 
It is paid iii human suffering.

W arning baffles officials 
San Antonio officials were baffled 
Friday morning after a curious memo from Washington was posted on bulletin boards, then ordered re­ moved later in the day. 
Dr. Cou rand Rot lie, director of the Sun An­ tonio 
Metropolitan 
Health Department, re­ layed a warning sent by a postal official concerning a deadly chemical being mailed to varioug go­ vernment officials. 
The substance was de­ scribed as “ Lance,” a highly toxic tear gas. the memo explained 
The warning letter said tasting the talcum- powder appearing che­ mical could result in in­ stant death, while breathing the substance would cause permanent brain damage. 
Whoever had mailed the deadly letters to officials posted them from Zip Code 11367, the memo continued

By ROBERT TIEMANN 

Twenty-eight works by the late George White, 
Jr., primitive artist from 
Cedar S prings, are on d isp lay at the C a rv e r 
C o m m u n ity 
C u ltu ra l 
Center through March 15. 
Whereas folk art is a byproduct of necessity in a non-industrial society, primitive art is the non­ utilitarian work of the unschooled in an indus­ trial society. 
White, therefore, was a primitive artist who used the folk art technique of 
■wood carving which he learned whiie stationed in Africa with the Army. 
White’s 13 tableaus are peopled by c a rv e d fi­ gures and magazine cu­ touts arranged in story*

Community Center. fForty Carats’ iii final show 

The last perform ance of the held-over comedy at Theater San Antonio, 
“ Forty Carats,” will be presented at 8.15 p.m. 
Saturday. 
The show about a m id­ dle-aged women having a romance with a man in his 2os has been held over for two w ee k en d s 

 b ec a u s e of se ll-o u t houses 
“ Forty C a ra ts” stars 
Mary Denman and Bob 
Hoop, two local television personalities, in the lead roles.

735-6922, opens at 7 p.m. Saturday.

A m«n could retire nicely in his old age if he could dis­ pose of his experience for what it cost him. 
In the 1979 Bridge Olym­ pics, tw o long stan d in g partnerships squared off in the match between Canada and France. Aces Sammy 
Kehela and Erie Murray of 
T oronto, known as the 
“hommes de fer” because of their long stints at the table, were faced by Henri Svarc and Jean Michel Boulanger, 
Europe’s equivalent of “iron men. The French scored the first blow in today's interest­ ing deal but the Canadians fought back {gamely and the match ended in a draw. 
At both tables West opened bid a 

2/S-A 

 one club and N o rth 
„ vulnerable three spades. 
After East’s pass, France’s 
Boulanger tried three no trump while Bruce Gowdy of 
Canada raised to four spades. 
A gainst C an ad a’s four spades. East lead the king of hearts and there was no chance. Eventually, North gave up four red suit losers and Canada lost IOO points. 
Against France’s three no trump, Murray led the club three and declarer had few problems. He won with his queen, finessed in spades and reentered his hand with the ace of hearts. Now he remem­ bered to cash the club ace before repeating the spade finesse and Boulanger scored an overtrick -- 93o more points to France. 
Boulanger made a wise choice in selecting the nine trick game. Even against a heart led by West, declarer can manage to scramble home. He takes two spade finesses for seven tricks and, coupled with South’s two aces, this gives him nine tricks and a well earned game advantage. 
In retrospect, the three no tr ump bid seems much 
Royal named river mayor 

Rio 
Ramblings 

Darrell Royal, Univer­ sity of T exas a th letic d irector, w as nam ed honorary mayor of the 
G reat C ountry 
R iver 
Festival at opening cere­ monies Friday night. 
Last year I Royal was commissioned an admir­ al of Paseo del Rio dur­ ing the river festiv a l, with special docking pri­ vileges along the River 
Walk. 
An avid country-w es­ tern m usic fan. Royal will again attend the en­ tire weekend of the festi­ val. 
Remodeling 
The R iver W alk A d­ visory C om m ission ap­ proved remodeling plans for two River Walk bu­ sin e s se s d uring last week’s monthly meeting. 
Architect Bill Longfel­ low presented plans to the com m ission for the second-phase remodeling of Caffe M ichelino. The plans call for a new landscaped brick pntio and in stallation of old* tim e ceiling fans in the outside balcony. 
R iver W alk C om m is sion m em bers also ap proved p lans for con ­ struction of a river-level en tra n ce at 
R iver 
Square. 
Construction 
Construction will begin in three weeks, according lo owner Bill Atwell 
Ed Klar of Concord 
P roperties also briefed commission members on plans for the Western In­ ternational Hotel 
The 646-room hotel, to be built at the M arina 
"ite on the river exten 
Mon, w ill featu re i river-themed restaurant and lounge, as w ell a river4eve! waterfalls.

Cellist returns for TU recital 

Affliate artist, cellist 
Gilberto M unguia, will return to Trinity Univer­ sity Saturday for three weeks of performances. 

While in San Antonio he will give a public re­ cital with the T rin ity 
Choir Feb. 2o at the uni­ versity’s chapel, and an appearance Feb. 19 at the new Carver Community 
Cultural Center. 

Others 

Munguia will also per­ form for various schools, civic, professional and cu ltu ral o rganizations. 
The m usician last worked with T rinity in 
O ctober. Since then he has released a new re ­ cord, which has been no­ m inated for a G ram m y 
Awald.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS—— Saturday Feb 5 1977 

TU’s 'Earnest’ is pleasant show 

GILBERTO MUNGUIA 
. . . at Trinity 

By RON WHITE 
If Trinity U niversity’s pro­ duction of “The Importance of 
Being Earnest” is not a funny show, it is at least pleasant. 
But being pleasant is the least one expects of Oscar Wilde’s comedy pok­ ing fun at the social restrictions of the upper class. It is probably close to impossible to do an outright poor job of 
“ E a rn e st.” W ilde’s drollery sim ply won’t permit it. 
W ilde’s wit comes through intact. 
His way of refusing to take anything serious other than the trivial results in his famous dicta. He was against din­ ing with relatives and flirting with one’s own husband (both disgraces). 
He considered it vulgar to talk like a dentist, m orbid to have m oral sym ­ pathy with invalids. 
To Wilde, losing one parent was un­ fortunate, but to lose both was care­ lessness. And his characters lack “ the high m oral tone th at is hardly conducive to health or happiness.” 
Wit 
W ith such a high ra te of wit in 
“ E a rn e st,” the lines can alm ost be allowed to speak for themselves. But they would, of course, be better re ­ ceived if the Trinity production’s di­ rector, Robert Boyard, had succeeded in establishing a style for his play. 

Review 

As W ilde wrote on another topic, with “ Earnest” style is everything and 
Sincerity is nothing. The Trinity pro­ duction wavers between extrem e sty­ lishness and foolish sincerity. 
Gary Clark as John Worthing, who p reten d s to he his n e’er-do-w ell brother, Earnest, whenever he is in the city, achieves the best balance of style and character. He is sly and amusing, giving each line a solid tongue-in- cheek treatm ent 
Damon Davis, as Algernon, John’s friend, who also im personates E ar­ nest. is played in an entirely different style by Damon Davis. l)a \is m akes his character a devilish gay blade, with an emphasis on gay. His legs and arms are constantly swishing about to the point of distracting from his lines. 
When he delivers Wilde’s famous epi­ gram that “ divorces are made in Hea­ ven ,” he does so with a form al ap­ proach to the audience that robs the line of any lightness. 
Fiancees 

As the two m en’s fiancees, M idge 
Woolsey and Georgetta Shelton both lack the bubble-headedness that one would think appropriate to two young 

 women who insist they will not m arry anyone not named Earnest. 
Woolsey, while too m ature for the role, does have a fine sense of comic ' timing and expression If she doesn’t I make a perfect Gwendolen, she is still * an interesting actress. Shelton is mis- » cast and seems unable to adapt to the ; 
English accent. 
In su p p o rtin g roles, E lla -Mao 
Brainard as Gwendolen’s mother, ful­ fills another character’s description of her as a monster, but, unfairly, not a myth. Michael Boyd as Canon Chasu­ ble has a fine sim pleton’s expression that one suspects Wilde would have approved of when worn by a clergy­ man. 
Overall, Bovard’s direction lacks the sparkle needed to accompany Wilde’s wit. Even a rough diamond can dazzle, but the sparkles would be even better. 

C irc u s o ffe rin g fre e p e rfo rm a n c e 

Circus Vargas, which will be in San 
Antonio Feb. 18-22, will give a free performance for 5,IHM) senior citizens and persons being helped by charitable organizations. 

The free performance will be at 4:3o p.m. Feb. 22.

SUMMARY - Persis­ tent selling of blue chip issues this week and switching of funds into secondary issues brought a drop of 9.H4 in the Dow while the N YSE index (a broader measure of the market) had a tiny loss of 
o.o3. For the first five weeks of 1977, the Dow has lost 5.7 per cent w hile the loss in the N YSE in­ dex has been only 4 2 per cent.

N EW YO RK (A B ) - 
The stock market recorded a small gain in an erratic session Friday as investors kept a wary eye on the weather out­ look. 
The Dow Jones average of 36 industrial stocks, which sank to a two- mouth low on Thursday, edged up .75 to 947.89 At its peak for the day the average had been ahead about 4 points. 
Gainers held a 7-5 ad­ vantage over losers on the New York Stock 
Exchange. 
Big Board volume to­ talled 
23.13 million shares against 23.79 mil­ lion Thursday. 
In each of the past three weeks the market has staged a quiet upsw­ ing on Friday after losses iii the previous few ses­ sions. 
Decline 
This week’s 9.64-point loss for the Dow left it w itll a net decline of 56.76 points for the first five weeks of 1977. 
Analysts traced some buying interest Friday morning to the latest weekly figures from the 
Federal R eserve, which showed an unexpected drop iii the money sup­ ply. The news tended to ease fears that the Fed might soon move to tighten credit. 
But no real enthusiasm developed iii the face of continuing concern over the prospective economic impact of severe cold w inter weather. 
As the market closed 
Friday, forecasts wi re calling for more frigid temperatures i i i the eas­ tern half of the country over the weekend. 
Employment 

Trading wasn't much affected by the sharp drop in tin* unemployment rate reported by the Labor 
Department 
Friday morning. The measur­ ement was taken before short supplies of natural gas forced widespread plan) closings and lav offs 

 i ii the last hull of 
January. 
The White House said 
President Carer expected the .jobless rate to rise in 
February because of the weather problems. 
Standard & Poor's in- 
’dex of 46o industrial stocks inched up o2 to 
113.o9, and 
S & P ’s 
5oo-stock composite in­ dex was up .o3 at IHI HS. 
Earnings 

Gulf & Western Indus­ tries. the day’s most ac­ tive issue, gave up I 5** to 
14;i*. On Thursday the company estimated fts first quarterly earnings decline ut more than five vicars.

O s 

According to the latest 
Agriculture Dept. Cattle 
Census, our national total was indicated at 
123,66o.66o head as of 
January I. 
The breakdown by weight classes shows that the forecast for heifers is 
9 per cent above last year while steers — 566 lbs. and over — were esti­ mated at only I per cent below the pres ions year. 
These figures were higher than had been an­ ticipated and suggest that during 1977 beef supplies will he ample. 
Live beef cattle futures have traded recently i i i a range of 38 cents to 46 cents per pound for April delivery, and have trend­ ed lower during the past year. 
Barge traffic has been slowed to a halt on the 
Mississippi River due to ice blockages aud as a result, movement of gram shipments mer tilts much-used route to the gulf ports has been prac­ tically nil 
A rather large price

Cohn, vice president, sales division. Nan An­ tonio office. Barile liai­ se v Stuart Inc, 

 differential lias deve­ loped between local mid­ western (“levators and these warm water ports, but the situation is tem­ porary and a drastic change in these differ­ ences will be rn the offing when the ice melts. 

Also iii the news is the drought problem iii the western states which may block fan n ers’ plans to increase their acreage for some crops.

Fair Oaks features Don Smith home 

FA IR O A K S this w e e k e n d fe a tu re s a tw o -sto ry , fo u r-b e d ro o m a n d th re e -b a th co u n try m a n o r tu c k e d into a fiv e -a c re h illsid e a t 7 6 4 5 P im lico 

F a ir Oaks, situated in the spectacular Hill Country just 16 minutes northwest of San An­ tonio. offers country living just as you want it to be. 
It’s a world of birds, wind rustling through trees, wild flowers, quail, dove and the sights of deer grazing in grassy meadows and clearings. 
Prime wooded acreage 
Some 5.(WM) acres of the former Fair 
Ranch have been carefully developed to offer buyers tracts of prime wooded acreage for homesites from ‘J U to 15 acres in size. 

The rolling hills and valleys of Fair 
Oaks span three counties — Bexar. 
Kendall and Comal — presenting a choice of many hilltop sites with views for miles. The project incorporates hiking trails, bridle paths and well paved, wide roads which provide ideal biking conditions. 

The Don Smith Co. is building out­ standing homes in Fair Oaks. Deserv­ ing the spotlight is the formidable re­ sidence tucked into the graceful five- acre hillside at 7H45 Pimlico. 
. •' „ z 

A visit to this two-story, four-be­ droom and three-bath country manor will im m ediately convince you that 
“ high” living here has more to it than altitude. A sweeping drive takes you up the hillside to the entrance. Stone columns across the entry porch tell you you’re in for something special. This home has, by far. one of the most un­ ique floor plans seen. Once inside, it becomes clear by its impressive foyer with large ceram ic tiles underfoot; wall covering with foil background; and trees in warm brow ns, deep golds and tans. For convenience, there is a cedar-lined coat closet with double louvered doors. 

Featured on the second story is a large, soft-gold carpeted living-dining room with cathedral ceiling; massive rock fireplace and hearth; double win­ dows; and, on either side, sliding . glass doors, one to a wooden deck and the other to a tile deck. Both have wooden balcony railings, and the view is indescribable! 

A serving bur opens to the bright green and white kitchen with all-elec­ tric appliances, including a countertop 

 griddle, .lust a step away is the break­ fast room with wrap-around picture windows, a built-in china cabinet and side-board. A well planned utility room with an abundance of storage lies dow n a short hall. 
The second-floor living area also contains a guest room; bath; and a spacious muster bedroom, with sliding glass doors to the tile deck, a wall of library shelves and a wall mural. The carpet here is a crisp lettuce-green velvet shag. A dressing room lie s 

 beyond with sand-lone marble vanity, double lavatories, dual m irrors and twin "his-n-hcrs” walk-in closets. 
A step through double doors leads to a bath that is “ right out of Hollywood.” 
The center of attention focuses on the sunken, gold-flecked tile tub with curved step and giant transluscent window. A separate shower room completes this striking room. 
The lower story of the home ia ac­ cessible by a carpetihI stairway. This level houses the ltt by 24-foot game 

 room with its rock fireplace and re­ cessed wood storage, shuttered win­ dows and sliding glass doors to a peb- ble-finish patio. A weathered wood wet bar. complete with built-in refrigera­ tor and closet, provides an ideal set­ ting for teen or adult gatherings. 
Two bedrooms and a decorator bath complete the lower-level floor plan. 
Oui' of these large bedrooms features triple, almost floor-to-coiling windows; a built-in desk; book shelves; and dou­ ble closets. 

Residents w ill find another big 
“ plus" for living iii Fair Oaks. 
First-rate recreational facilities, iii a rustic setting, will be offered by the 
F'air Oaks Racquet and Swim Club 
Fight new tennis courts are now com­ pleted. The complex includes a sw m i­ nting pool and rock clubhouse with a viewers’ deck across the front, shaded by the giant oaks of the area. 
F l a n s are already confirm ed for 
Mike Moore to provide quality, pro­ fessional t e n n i s instruction at F a ir 

Oaks. Moore will be working eloselv with business partner Bill O’Bryant of 
M cF a rlin Tennis Center to provide1 year-round tennis programs t Fair Oaks properties are within the boundaries of tIn* Boerne School Dis triet. 
Fair Oaks is reached most easily bv driving north of NAV III ll). I',xii at 
I.eon Springs, then proceed north oil the* access road to the Camp Stanlev sign. Turn right and guilty miles to tin- 
Fair ( laks ollice

EQUAL HOUSING 
Available o p p o r t u n it y 

 ing - developing firm s mo^t popular se rie s of housing this weekend. 
F re e d o m H om es, a series which has enjoyed trem endous popularity because of its affordable p rice ra n g e , will be modeled in the northeas­ tern Bexar County neigh­ borhood in the Universal 
City vicinity. 
Near sites 

C im arro n , a s do all 
Morton / Southwest com­ m unities, boasts an ad ­ vantageous location not only by virtue of provid­ ing a real panoram a of c o u n try sid e h ills and trees but also quick, easy d riv in g d ista n c e s to a number of m ajor destin­ ation points. 

F e a tu rin g affo rd ab lv priced new homes in this s e r ie s , C im arro n is a value-keyed community with fash io n s that com plem ent its rustic, western and back - to - nature setting that yields peace and quiet to all its residents. 

The location of Cim ar­ ron also m eans no San 
Antonio taxes apply to the new homes in the co­ lorful community, which of course, calls for lower m onthly p a y m en ts. 
These payments, in fact, are quite affordable just by the h o m e s’ p rice range, starting as low' as 
$28,5oo! 

As well. Cim arron re­ 

 sidents can enjoy nearby am en ities, including a swim club, club h ouse. 
Scout hut and complete playgroun d for y o u n g­ sters. 

Much as well. more is nearby 

For in stance, C im a r ­ ron is situated within the p ro g re ssiv e 
Ju d so n 
School D istrict and a l ­ most next door to Kitty 
Hawk Middle School. 

Kitty Hawk Drive itself is soon to be a m a jo r route through a well de­ veloped sector of north­ 

 eastern Bexar County. It is being extended from 
N.E. FM 16o4 all the way to 
C restw a y 
D rive, which, in turn, provides quick access to N.E. Ill 
35 by su b u rb an W ind­ crest. 

Kitty Hawk Drive pre­ sently le a d s to 
Pat 
Booker Road in Univer­ sal City and its fine shopping facilities, re s­ ta u r a n ts, b an k s, churches and places of entertainment, as well as the m ain en tra n ce to 
Randolph AFB. 

So quiet and peaceful is 

Cimarron, though, that, while enjoying the seren­ ity which excludes any city traffic noises, a resi­ dent could momentarily forget all these a d v a n ­ tages are so close to his own home. 

The com m u n ity is reach ed m ost eaybv exiting from N E. Ill 35 to N.E. FM 16o4 and pro­ ceed in g e a st to Kitty

FURNISHED MODELS OPEN DAILY ’TIL DUSK. 
658-4793 

 continued at stro n g le­ vels, as statistics for the year just ended are compiled. 

It se e m s that 
1976 proved to be the biggest year on record for tile lo­ cal Multiple Listing Ser­ vice, accordin g to Ray 
R a g sd ill, p resid en t of 
San Antonio B oard of 
Realtors Inc. 
Highest ever 

The total sales dollar volume for the year was in excess of $343 million highest ever for MLS in 
San Antonio. The p r e ­ vious year's sales totaled just under $156 million. 

The local 
M ultiple 
Listing Service, operated by SA B U R , is an a r ­ ran gem ent where each broker brings his listings to the attention of other members. 

When a sa le re su lts, the commission is divid­ ed between the broker bringing the listing and the broker m akin g the sale. The MLS works to the a d v a n ta g e of both seller and buyer by plac­ ing information about a piece of property in the han ds of all m e m b e rs who, iii turn, pass it on to their clionts. 
According to Ragsdill, many of the homes sold were e x istin g hom es, which, on today’s m a r­ ket, move rapidly and at good prices. 
Sales are up nationally, too. Speaking recently iii 
D a lla s, H arry G. E lm - strom , president of the 
National Association of 
Realtors, pointed out that the 56o,ooo m em bers of his o rg a n iz atio n w it­ nessed a record-breaking year.

At The P ie r, no one lives “ in a fishbow I ." 
There's an inner circle of privacy. 
Cars come and go only on the outer perim eter, giving tenants ami guests easy access to the apart­ ments. 
Unmarred 
This leaves the luxur­ ious beauty of the sweep­ ing, central grounds and the attractive recreation­ al offerings of The Pier unmarred by traffic dis­ tu rb a n ce s. Sw im m in g and aunbathing or party­ ing in the pavilion have the feeling of privacy. 
Residents may entertain or just plain relax out­ doors in a truly peaceful setting. 
I f s a park-like atmos­ phere, complete with lit­ tle lakes and moats, lawn chairs and tallies, trees 

 and pretty plantings. The scene from the fun area at The P ier doesn't in­ clude passing traffic. But passing ducks, yes! 
It s great living indoors at The Pier. too. Many of its ap artm en ts are w a­ terside; all are luxurious 
All have decks or patios. 
Various one-and two-bed­ room units become av ailab le from time to tune, both furnished and unfurnished. There are particular plans favored by sh a rin g sin g le s or students. Some are most suitable for the married couple — fam ily living d e sig n s. C ertain p lan s include a “ bonus room,’’ ideal for an office at home, a small den or ll-

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Feb 5 1977 
Builders foresee ‘super year’ for homes 

By FRANK 
MANUPELLI 
PRESIDENT, 
GREATER S A 
BUILDERS 
ASSO CIATIO N 
“ Housing will bo the s t a r of th e ec o n o m ic show” in 1977, economist 
W a lte r H e lle r told a meeting of the nation’s home builders in Dallas recently. 
H is a u d ie n c e w as equally confident. “ We look for this to be one of th e m o st p re d ic ta b le housing years in recent m e m o ry , and t h a t ’s g o o d ,’’ sa id M alcolm 
Prine, president of Ryan 
Homes Inc., Pittsburgh. 
The consensus of the builders who g ath ered for the National Associa­ tion of Home B uilders 
Convention is that there is going to be a housing boom in 1977 and that, even now, the housing industry is resum ing its place as a leader in the economy. 

The o p tim ism am ong the 
55,ooo b u ild e r s , lenders and suppliers in 
D allas has been w id e s­ pread. “ We had a super year last year, and this year will be even better,” say s G e o rg e S. W rite r 
Jr., president of W riter 
Corp. of Englewood, Col. 
He e x p ects to in c re ase co n s tru c tio n by 3o per cent th is y e a r. But, he warns, “ Inflation will be tw ice as bad as last y e a r , ” w hen 
IO a c ro s s -th e -b o a rd p rice increases gave W riter a scant .4 per cent increase in profit m argins. 
Even so. M ichael Su- m ic h r a s t, th e N A H B ’s chief economist, believes that “ i f s going to be a very good y ear.” He pre- 

" t u u m w u T 

FRANK MANUPELLI 

 diets that a total of 1.84 million housing units will be started in 1977. This figure, which has been revised upward in recent weeks, would be a 2o per cent in c re a se from the 
1.54 m illion u n its c o m ­ pleted in 197H and would be th e fo u rth h ig h e st since the Census Bureau b egan k ee p in g such records in 1959. The re ­ cord was set in 1972 with 
2.38 million units. 
A booming housing in­ d u stry g en e rally helps stimulate the rest of the econom y. 
N ew -hom e production affects sales not only of such building m aterials as lumber, in­ sulation and concrete but also of household item s like appliances and fur­ niture. Thus, “ fur every d o lla r sp e n t on new housing, $2.5o is spent in 

 s u p p o r t,” S u m ic h r a s t calculates. Spending on housing construction, in­ cluding rem o d elin g , is expected to hit a record 
$69 billion in 1977, up by 
17.1 per cent from 1976. 
Housing’s job impact is s im ila rly b ro ad . The building of an additional 
3oo,ooo housing units in 
1977 would add 6oo,ooo jobs in the construction industry, w here the un­ employment rate is about 
14 per cent. 
It would ad d m an y more mobs in supporting industries, according to 
Sum ichrast. And the in­ d u s t r y ’s h ig h ly f r a g ­ m e n ted n a t u r e m e a n s that this impact would be felt nationwide. Of some one million construction firms, fewer than .4 per cent em ploy over 1,ooo w orkers, and no single company produces more than .5 per cent of total new housing. 
In demand 
B u ild ers say the s in ­ g le -fam ily h o m e m ay have its best year ever. 
The hom e b u i l d e r s ’ group predicts that sin ­ gle-fam ily housing p ro ­ duction will to tal 1.35 million units in 1977, up 
15 per cent from 1976’s healthy 1.17 million and well above 1972’s record 
1.31 million. 
B uilders a re p a r tic u ­ larly encouraged by Un­ stable financing outlook. 
“ We believe 1977 will bo a y e a r of p len tifu l s u p p lie s of m o rtg a g e credit,” says Donald M. 
Kaplan, chief economist of the F e d e ra l Hom e 
Loan Bank Board. The flow of funds into savings b an k s th is y e a r is e x ­ pected to approach the 

— ------ Cl ASS IW B B i m A Y ------------------ 

 record level of 1976, be­ cause of attractive inter­ est rates and continued consumer caution. 
“Our business through the w in ter m o n th s w as the best it’s been in the last 15 or 2o years,” says 
Mel Green, an Iowa City builder. D ecem b er and 
J a n u a r y s a le s w ere so good for Wood B ros. 
Homes Inc. that William 
T u ck er, executive vice president, is reassessing an earlier forecast of a 15 per ce n t g ain in s a le s from 1976’s 2,ooo units in 
D en v e r, H ouston and o th er citie s. In its N o­ v e m b e r-Doce in ber s u r ­ vey of c o n s u m e r c o n fi­ d en ce, th e C o n fere n ce 
Board, the private busi- n e s s -re s e a rc h g ro u p , found 4.2 p e r ce n t of those it surveyed intend­ ed to buy a house within six m o n th s , up a full percentage point from its 
Septem ber-O ctober s u r ­ vey. 
In ad d itio n , b u ild e rs see predicted 1977 sales of re c o rd 3 4 m illion older homes as a factor in their favor. “ People who were going to buy a new house for years now are able to trade up be­ cause of the tremendous values they’re able to get out of their used homes,” says Sandy Krulak, p re­ sid en t of 
W inslow 
Homes. Iii California, for ex a m p le , .“ people who bought for $25,ooo IO or 15 y e a rs ago can sell for 
$5o,ooo and put th e ir m oney into a new house,” says Robert Le- venstein, executive vice president of Kaufman & 
Broad Inc. 
Almost without ex­ ception, builders are 

 abandoning the low-cost, no-frills homes that were the talk of last y e a r ’s convention. “ H ousing’s equivalent to the Pinto is no longer the a n s w e r,” says Levenstein, whose company helped initiate the back-to-basics trend two y ears ago. “ W e’re building slightly la rg er houses with more am en ­ ities th a t the tra d e -u p b u y er w a n t s .” 
A dds 
F ra n k C ro sse n , c h a i r ­ man of Centrex: “ People who want low-cost hous­ ing a re b u y in g used houses.” 
Multi-family 

The m ulti-fam ily out­ look varies from city to city. Those who plan to build m ore a p a rtm e n ts believe occupancy levels and rents in existing un­ its are high enough and m ortgage rates are low 

Not facts 

I f you are being "sold” on converting your heat­ ing system to some other type, move cautiously. 
The s a le sm a n ’s claim s are not necessarily facts, regardless of his appar­ ent logic. 

The realities can best judged by calling in a salesm an of com peting types of sy s te m s , s u g ­ g ests the B e tte r H e a t­ ing-Cooling Council, and p re s e n t him w ith the claim s the other fellow made. After you’ve heard both sides, you will be in a better position to judge what is best for you. 

 enough to m a k e new building feasible again. 
F o r e x a m p le , in San 
Antonio, where the occu­ pancy rate is over 9o per cent and rents are rising by IO to 15 p er c e n t a year, builder Quincy Lee is planning three projects totaling 3oo to 4oo units, his first in three years. 
Until recently, with oc­ cupancy rates at 8o per cent or below and utility bills tripling, “ We just couldn’t have made any money building ap art­ m e n ts ,” he says. Now, a p a r tm e n t b u ild in g m o rtg a g e r a te s in the area have declined to 9t2 per cent on a 3o-year loan from last y ear’s levels of 

912 for 27 years, he adds. 
The b u ild ers a s so cia­ tio n ’s S u m ic h ra s t c a u ­ tions that, in many areas, including New York and 
Florida, builders of p ri­ vate rental units “ face m a jo r, lo n g -te rm and m ostly unsolvable pro b ­ le m s ” re la te d to still- high m ortgage rates or u n a v a ila b le fin a n c in g and to the existence or th reat of ren t controls. 
“ The incentive to invest in them just isn’t there,” 
Sumichrast adds. n e a r l y , home buyers face sharply higher price tags. Most bu ild ers ex­ pect construction costs to rise at least IO per cent, and buyers’ costs are li-

This New Home 
Costs Less Than 
Your Old Home. 

I'm Buddy Burns. Ami I’d like to shed some light on your old home, lf your home is 
5 years old or older, chances are it's obsolete. 
That's right, obsolete. Be­ cause at the time your hom e was built, there were virtually no energy-etii- ctency standards. As a result, many San Antonians are faced with utility bills that may soon exceed their house payments! 

Why NOW Is The Tim e To Buy. 
Let's look at the tacts. Since you invested in your home a few years ago, two things have hap pened. For one, you've been making house payments tor sev­ eral years, so your equity h a s grown. Too, since the cost of building a new home has stead­ ily increased, the cost of replac­ ing your home has increased. 
BUT, because your old home isn't energy efficient, it wastes valuable energy. And believe it or not, homeowners around the country arc actually beginning to lose money when they sell their older h o m e s . Because no­ 

 body wants to buy a home where the cost of heating and cooling exceeds the monthly payments 
My advice is this: With the money you can make by selling 
\o u r old home light now, you can probablv m a ke the daw n- pavnient and m in e into a new burns Co. Power Saver* hom e today. And, w hile your house payments may he a little higher, the lower utility hills should easily offset the difference. The only thing you can't afford to do is wait much longer.

 im pact on m any seg­ ments of the economy, the homeowner's basic tax benefits remain in­ tact. notes Larry Resow of Resow & Kline, Real­ tors. 

Interest payments on mortgage loans can still be deducted on the ho­ m eowner’s 1976 tax re­ turn, as can payments for local property taxes. 
“ The dollar amounts of these deductions help m illions of fam ilies re­ duce their ye arly tax bills,” declares Resow. 

Adverse effect 

The 1976 Tax Reform 
Bill has an adverse effect for those taxpayers who have been able to deduct 

 at-home office expenses in the past. 

As a member of RULO. the nation's largest not- for-profit relocation ser- vice, Rosow & K lin e. 
Realtors, serves many people moving into. San 
Antonio for job-related reasons. A great number of people like these work at home during evenings and on weekends. Resow reports, but. under the new tax provisions, very few will be able to take at-home office space ex­ pense deductions this year 

To qualify for home of­ fice space deductions, tax accountants and atto r­ neys provide the follow­ ing guidelines. 

•Incom e produced from the home office must be the taxpayer s p rim ary source of in ­ come. 

• In dual career fa­ m ilies — one salaried and the other self-em ­ ployed — incom e pro­ duced from the home of­ fice must be the primary source of income report­ ed on a joint return 

• Salaried executives and em ployes whose companies provide office space aw ay from the home will not be able to deduct for at-home office space expenses, lf an em ployer requ ires an employe to work at home on special projects and if

 lf a homeowner can qualify for at-home office space expense deductions under these stringent restrictions, the space must be used exclusively for business-related, in­ com e-producing p u r­ poses. MORTON/SOUTHWEST 

(OUT O F T O W N C A L I COLLECT) 
WRITE P O B O X 18428 
S A N A N T O N IO , TEXAS 1 8 2 8 6 

Recent accounts in media in­ dicate that prices of homes have been escalating faster than fa­ mily incomes and that many house hunters are finding a first-time purchase beyond their means. 
"Tile situation in San Antonio is not as bad as such reports would lead us to believe,” said Ray Ragsdill, president of the San Antonio Board of Realtors. 

Median price 

"W hile it is true that, in the I 
S. today, the median price of a new home is $39,ooo. almost twice what it was IO years ago, homes in San Antonio can be purchased for considerably less.” continues Ragsdill. 
During the last three mouths of 1976, data from the board's Multiple Listing 
Service indicate that the average price of homes sold in San Antonio was about 
$27,ooo, he said 
Ragsdill served as last year’s chair­ man of the M KS. an arrangem ent where each broker brings Ids listings to tile attention ol other board members. When a sale results, the commission is divided between the broker bringing the listing and tilt' broker m aking the salt*. The M KS works to tilt' advantage of both seller and buyer by placing inform ation about a piece of property in the hands of all member brokers who in turn 

 pass it on to their clients. lastings in­ clude both new and existing homes. 
Elven iii the northwestern quadrant of Bexar County, with its many luxury homes, the average salt' price for 
October, November and December was only $35,567, well under tilt' national average 
Citing a report released in November bv tilt' Texas Real bistate Research 
Center at Texas .W M U n iv e rsity , 
Ragsdill noted that the tv picul Texas 
Fam ily would be better off finaneiall.v by $134.66 per month by investing in home ownership 
Calculations in the W M study were based on a family vs itll ail annual in­ come of $16.o(16 purchasing a new 
$4o,ooo home financed over 3o years at an annual interest rate set at 9 per cent. Pile assumption was that the m arket v alin* of the home would appreciate 8 per cent per year and that the familv would hold the borne for five vears. A comparable rental unit, in­ cluding utilities, would cost $4oo per month. 
Tax advantages and the profit lea 
11/od from the sail* of the home are the factors winch make borne purchase financially advantageous, the AXM re- pert concluded. 
"And one must not lose sight of tin* many reasons other than financial for owning one s own home," said Rags­ dill "It s still the American Dream to own a home which meets one’s special needs and tastes, where one can deve­ lop a feeling of belonging and pride

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Feb 5 1977 All Points convenes in S.A. 

Deanie O w ens C o 
Realtors, has added a recent office at 9 o 3 o 
W urzbach Rd. in the Turtle Creek area. Its staff includes, in front row, 
M rs. Doris Pocock, Realtor-owner; second row, from left, Bernice 
M acTaggart, M a ry Harder, N onie Rom ans and G loria Resendez; third row, same order, M arian M cM ullin and Emi Jacobs; and, fourth row,

Advanced real estate subjects offered by SOARS 

 bPtCIA l to THI GOLDIN TWINS 
COLLEGE STATION - Heal estate professionals from across the nation will gather at Texas 
A&M University May 15 - 27 for the fourth annual session of the 
Studies of Advanced Heal Estate 
Subjects (SOARS). 

Sponsored by the Texas Heal Estate 
Research Center (TUERO and Texas 
A&M, the unique series of classes offers experienced real estate practi- cioners the opportunity to learn the latest concepts and techniques of the realty field. 

‘Tools needed’ 

“ SOARS students attend classes on the cam pus of Texas A&M for two weeks a year for three y e a rs ,” ex­ plained TRERC Director Dr. Alvin B. 
Wooten. “ At graduation, we believe they are equipped with the tools need­ ed to put them years ahead of their contemporaries.” 

In struction is org anized around three basic fields of study, the real estate investment decision, managing the practice of real estate and govern- ment-industry interface 

The 1978 session of SOARS included the first-class graduated from the pro­ gram. Students from ll states attended this session, and TRERC officials ex­ pect an even greater cross-section of representation in 1977. 

“ For years, real estate practitioners have had to rely on individual semin­ a rs. short cou rses and in stitu tes sprinkled across the country for their advanced professional education," ex­ plained SOARS C oordinator Gary llousley. 
“ With the advent of SOARS, it be­ cam e possible for them to receive education, not just training, in a for­ mal educational experience at a major university." 

Housle.v said the benefits of SOARS to the professional realty person are numerous. For example, students are required to be away from the office for only two weeks a year for three years; there are annual refreshers for g ra­ duates; and the faculty is carefully selected from both the real estate in­ dustry aud universities nationwide. 

To simulate real world activity in real estate, each SOARS student be­ gins his intermediate year as part of a management team whose purpose it is to apply what has been learned in the program. Each team makes a series of decisions designed to achieve the ob­ jectives developed by the team. 

Although prim arily built around brokerage, teams can buy inventory, take equity positions, establish lines of credit, acquire branch offices and generally expand into full-service firms. Feasibility/investment analysis and government regulations are inte­ grated into the simulation A full set of financials are computer-run for each team following each set of decisions. 
The computer even prepares listing, market and financial consulting infor­ mation. 

“The management simulation phase of SOARS was developed at considera­ ble cost,” explains llousley. “ It is the most sophisticate and up-to-date real estate simulation in existence, and it provides a valuable learning exper­ ience for SOARS students. 

"SOARS teaches the successful as­ sembly and presentation of complex financial pack ages, d e m o n stra te s methods of managing real estate firms more profitably and provides insight into governmental regulations while unveiling strategies for dealing with them." he added. 
Information regarding the 1977 ses­ sion of SOARS can be obtained by writing SOARS Coordinator, Texas 
Real Estate Research Center, Texas 
A&M University, College Station, TX 
77843. 

Deanie Owens Co., 
Realtors, of San Antonio played host to the r e ­ gional convention / con­ ference of the AH Points 
Relocation Service this past week. 
M em ber b rok ers a t ­ tending the conference were from Texas, Okla­ homa, A rkansas, Lo­ uisiana, M issouri and 
Georgia. 

Network 

All Points is a nation­ wide network of member 
Realtors who assist home buyers and sellers in re­ locating across the U.S. and into Mexico and many 
European countries. Deanie Owens 
Co. is the mem ber affi­ liate in San Antonio and has established one of the best track records in the nation for results. 

The convention / con­ ference began with a gala welcome reception in the 
River Room of the Con­ vention Center. Topics ranging from “ The Relo­ cation D irectors W ork­ shop” to “ C orporate 
Contact P resentations” kicked off the co n fer­ ences. 

The Deanie Owens Co. contingent to the con­ vention was headed by 
Robert E. Owens Sr., president. Out-of-town 

A ir leaks 

With weatherstripping around doors and win­ dows and caulking in tin cracks prevent sufficient air from coming into the house? G enerally not. 
The occasional opening of doors, plus the wind pressure on the outside provides adequate air for breathing. 

It is gen erally a s ­ sumed, says the Better 
Heating-Cooling Council, that there will be one complete change of air in the house every hour, and tests now' show that a tightly-built house will have a natural air change pretty close to that. Make sure, however, that there is sufficient additional air coming into the base­ ment to provide the oxy­ gen needed for fuel combustion in your heat­ ing unit.

Townhomes 

By TERRY WILBOURN 
COUNTY tXTCNStON Mo8TICUI TUBIST 

The production of high-quality 

 fruit, whether in our backyards or in a commercial orchard, doesn’t just happen. It takes careful planning and lots of work. 
I ’m afraid many of us fall into the procedure of dropping by the local outlet and buying “ Just” a fruit tree 
(or trees) and then run home and stick it in the ground. To obtain the greatest benefit from the tree, fruitwise, one has to plant it properly and control insects and diseases long after it is planted. 
Varietal selection 
The one aspect of fruit production many gardeners do urotig. from the start, is varietal selection. We choose varieties not adapted to South Texas conditions and then wonder why they do not perform very well. Sure. they may grow and have a few fruit; but. aren’t you after large, consistent yields year after year? 
An example would be the Elberta peach. It has got to be the best eating peach there is but not a consistent performer in San Antonio, peaches, as you may know, have to have a certain number of chilling hours (below 45° F ) before they will break dormancy and produce in the Spring. 
Different peaches have different chilling requirements (total hours). 
The Elberta peach requires a large number of chilling hours (around 9oo hours), as compared to 65o hours for 
June Gold. In normal W inters, we Just don't get enough hours under 45° F to satisfy the chilling requirements of gmWHBWfrHAY------- 

 an

AMONG THE TREES 
YET ONLY ONE

Elberta peach. This Winter may b* exception; but, this is true all over the country 
Also, with other types of fruit, there are requirements and problems with some varieties that make them unsui­ table for South Texas. Another thing to be careful of are ads in national ma­ gazines and the like that make certain fruit trees appear to perform well an­ ywhere in the country. Be sure you know th*' varieties that do well. 
Listed bt'low are varieties of certain fruits that do well hero in South Texas and are on the Texas Agricultural Ex­ tension Sen ice recommended list I am sure this list is not all inclusive but

Gardeners' Questions— Answers 

By TERR Y W ILBO l RN 
COUNTY tXTINSION NOETIC UlTURISf 
We planted an apricot tree several yours ago. and borers got into it and killed it bal k. Shoots from low on the trunk have grown to form a fairly large tree, but we never get any fruit. What’s wrong? 

I am quite sure the tree will never produce fruit. was grafted to begin with, and the shoots you speak of come from be­ low the graft. This part of the trunk is from a see dling, and growth from this rootstock probably 

 lf it does, It will not be like the varie ty you bought. By the way. apricots don't do well in our San Antonio climate ani wa). 

Questions on various aspects of lawn, garden or plant care, as well os landscaping, can be answered in this column. Please address any correspondence to the columnist himself ond not to this newspaper. Arquillo to le a d builders 

S S fC IA l T O TMI O O I D I N T W IN S 
WASHINGTON - Ro­ bert Arquilla. a Chicago builder, was elected pre­ sident of the National 
Association of Home 
Builders by the board of directors at its meeting in Dallas last week. 
Elected to serve with 
Arquilla as senior na­ tional officers of the as­ sociation were Ernest A. 
Becker br. of Las Vegas, first vice president; Van­ dal S. Gravies of B ir ­ mingham. vice president and treasurer; and Mer- 
Til Butler. Irvine, ( alif., vice president and secre­ tary. 
Arquilla has been ac­ tive in building for the past 24 years as owner of the Burnside Construe- 
I lion Co. of Glenwood. III. 
His company specializes 
I in building single-family 
' dwellings and condomin- 
; iums and in the develop- i ment of commercial and industrial land 
He was first vice president in 
1978.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Feb 5 I977 
6o days averaged for time for sales 

SANDRA CAILLOUETTE 

M a n a g e r appointed by SABO R 

Hay Kagsdill, presi­ dent of San 
Antonio 
Board of Realtors Inc.. has announced tin* ap­ pointment of Sandra 
Caillouette to the position of general office manager for SABOR. 

Ms. ( aillouette is a na­ tive San Antonian and a graduate of 
Alamo 
Heights High School and 
Incarnate Word College. 
She joined the staff of 
SABOR in .lune, I RT B. 
She is a member of the 
Anacacho Chapter of the 
National Secretaries As­ sociation. 

Homes listed for sale in Bexar 
County sell, on the average, within (ii) days. 

Increasingly, more homes are being put up for sale, and the dollar volume of these sales continues to rise both here and across tilt' nation. 

N ow ’s tim e 

“ Now is truly a good time to sell a house,” said Hay Ragsdill, president of San Antonio Board of Realtors Inc. and last year's chairman of the Multi­ ple Listing Service conducted by the ixia rd. 
The MLS is an arrangement where each broker brings his listings to the attention of other members. When a sale results, the commission is divided between the broker bringing the listing and the broker making the sale. The 
MLS works to the advantage of both seller and buyer by placing informa­ tion about a piece of property in tin' hands of all member brokers who. in turn, pass it on to their clients. 

Data gathered from the MLS show it takes an averaged till days from the time a house is listed until it is sold 
“ Of course, many places sell much quicken.” said Ragsdill. 

During the quarter winch ended Dec. 

31. I HTH. a total of 756 homes sold in the northeastern sector of Bexar County for an,average price of $34,1o2, ac­ cording to MLS figures. Northwestern homes brought an average slightly higher. $33,5o7; there were o33 sold. 

Iii the southern part of the county, 
2o7 homes changed owners for an average price of $19,284 in the eastern half. The other half of southern Bexar 
County saw 3o8 homes sell for an average price of $19,414. 

Many of these sales represent, a change in ownership of existing homes. 

According to the National Associa­ tion of Realtors, sales rose o.9 per cent 

 iii November to reach a seasonally-ad­ justed, annual rate of 3,32o,ooo. slight­ ly below the peak of 3,33o.ooo estab­ lished in September. 

The November sales pace was 17.3 per cent higher than the same month a year ago and 38.9 per cent above No­ vember. 1974. when the real estate market was beset with high interest rates, inflation and recession. 
The dollar value of the existing homes sold during the month was $9.7 billion throughout the nation. Com­ pared with November a year ago, the median sales price of existing single- tamilv homes moved up 8.7 per cent from $35,7oo to $38,8oo.

HI ll III KS ASSOCIATION 

“ The past year proved the biggest and best in the history of the Multi­ ple Listing Service,” said 
Ray Ragsdill, president of the San Antonio Board of Realtors. 
The local 
M ultiple 
Listing Service, operated by SA BO R, is an a r­ rangement where each member company brings listings to the attention of more than 1,6oo other member companies and their sales associates. 
Advantages 
The MLS works to the advantage of both seller and buyer by placing in­ formation about a piece of property in the hands

621 and, in December a year ago, to 46o.”

In fact, the total sales dollar volume for 1976 for 
MLS was in excess of a staggering $243 million, highest ever for MLS in 

San Antonio. The 19/5 sales totaled just under 
$156 million.

The state attorney general’s office won a major victory Friday in its fight to make the former owner of a busi­ ness school chain pay 
$927.o(1o in refunded student tuitions. 
A 45th District C ourt jury found the corpora­ tions which composed 
I the chain, owned by 
Curl Welding, did not 
| function as true corporations and. as a result, Welding is re­ sponsible for their ac­ tions. j 
Because of the find­ ing. the attorney gener­ al’s office can argue 
Welding should person- 
I ally repay the $927.(NM) his school chain owes to former students. 
The question will be j argued before Bist, j Judge Robert Murray. 
I probably within the next one or two months. 
The jury returned its 
' finding after listening i to ll 1/2 days of testi­ mony concerning 
W elding's 
Southwest 
Inc,

Students should be 1 refunded any part of their unused tuition, I according to state law. , 
Under state law, the i stockholders of a cor­ poration are not held < responsible for the cor­ poration’s debts. 
However, Asst. Atty. . 
General W illiam 6. { 
Goodman said during I his final arguments 
Wehhng’s corporation’s j did not function as true corporations. 
They instead were vehicles for Wehling’s personal business trail- j suctions. 
Goodman said. 
The attorney gener­ al s suit against 
Uehling involves Pa r­ ish Draughon’s Busi­ ness College and Tech-! meal Institute in San 
Antonio and four other I schools in Texas. 
Seven other schools 
Uehling owned are also ; involved. 
Goodman recalled the week s testimony which | revealed Wehler’s cor­ porations did not have I stockholders’ meetings. i' en I mg s attorney, 
Kenneth Bean land, ar­ gued his client was not guilty because the tes­ timony failed to show his client had mis-1 represented any facts. 
Beanland also said i his client had I transferred funds between his schools simply to meet ex- i ponses 
$ 1 5 o ,o o o blaze traced to trash 

A $159.(KHI blaze in a Castle Hills residence 
Friday was believed started when a bag of trash iii the garage ignited. 
Castle Hills Fire Chief A. G, t ampa said the origin of the fin* at the C, K. Wingo residence at 
137 Iaiu Jon Circle was traced to the garage. 
Wingo, a local business executive, told investi­ gator* he had been awakened by a crackling siiund alxiut 4 45 a.in. und found heavy smoke and flames in the front part of tin* residence. 
Mr. and Mrs. Wingo and their 14-year-old daughter reportedly escaped unharmed through a rear door. 
Fire fighting units from Castle Hills and Balcon es Heights spent about an hour extinguishing tin* blaze, according to fire department rejwirts. 
The entire fi\e-bedroom residence sustained heavy smoke and water damage Must of the fire damage was limited to the front part of the home. 
Tampa said. t ampa said a plastic bag full of trash set next to a garage wall may have (tippled over und the debris ignited by a m al bv beater.

HOUSTON (AP) — Quarterback Dan Pastorini has told the 
Chicago Tribune he wants to be traded because he doesn’t like the Houston Oii?r “management, the fans or the town.” 

The T ribune said P astorini, 27, had asked to be traded to Los Angeles of the 
N ational Football League but that O iler Coach Bum Phillips had told the quarterback the R am s w eren’t interested. 
“ I don’t believe him (P h illip s) because I know b e tte r.” P asto rin i was quoted as saying. 
Asked about the T ribune story, P hillips said Thursday night,“ I don’t know anything about the story. He could have said those things. I'm not saying he didn’t. We are all hum an, but he’s been here (in Houston) all week and he didn t say anything to m e about being unhappy or wanting to be traded. 
“ You know it is a contract year for him . T h at’s the year when 9o per cent of the players ask to be traded or announce they are going to retire I’m not saying th a t’s the only reason why he said those things,” the coach said 
Last week P hillips said P astorini “ is our No. I quarterback and w e’re counting on him playing here next season. W e’re not discussing any trade for him , and don’t have any plans to do so.” 
The T ribune quoted P asto rin i as saying he also would like to play for 
Chicago because of Sid H illm an, the form er O iler coach who recently was nam ed offensive coordinator for the Bears.

Texas in the BO-yard dash at the 4th annual South­ west Conference Indoor Track and Field meet. 
E dm ond, a tran sfe r from Louisiana State, beat freshm an 
.Jones out of the blocks and the O lym pian could never m ake up the stride difference. Edm ond was tim ed in 6.25 while Jones was second at 6.28. 
Texas A&M’s Shilton B aker was an easy w inner in the HO yard hurdles with a 7:31. and Rice won the distance medley modal.

Ireland running for A rkansas, and Canadian Paul C raig of 
Texas both escaped the upset bug. 
O ’S h a u g h n e ssy e s ta b lis h e d a new SWC re c o rd in th e 
1,ooo-yard run in a tim e of 2:o6.75, breaking by alm ost five seconds the old record of 2:11.6 by Craig. 
Craig, who did not run at Texas last year to com pete for the 

V TH ICK H a s t-L T S , / ’ap,' IE 

Canadian Olym pic team , beat back a spirited bid by A rkansas’ 
Tom Aspel to win the m ile in 4:1o.5. Aspel was tim ed in 4:11.2 
C raig said, “ I’ve have the flu all week and I felt weak. I wanted to take the lead with four laps to go and I didn’t want to have to sprint at the finish. I thought I had been pushing it when Aspel went by me. He looked good but when he passed me it was off the curve and that m eant he had to work a little harder. That m ight have been the difference.” 
January ahead 
HONOLULU (A P) - Don 
January, the slow-moving, soft­ ly drawling self-styled “ Old 
Folks” of the pro tour, had to shoot an alm ost errorless eight-under-par 64 Friday to take the second-round lead in the $24o,(KIO Hawaiian Open Golf 
Tournament. 
“ One helluva a round for m e,” said the 47-year-old Jan u ary , the com eback 

✓ SC O R E S, P a g e I t 

 king who once quit the gam e for three years then returned, in his 4os, to play the best golf of his life. 
“ P robably the best score I’ve had since I’ve been b ack ,” said Jan u ary 
His heroics—as usual perform ed at a relax ed , casual, am bling pace—w ere 
* necessary to hold off form er Hawaiian 
Open cham p G rier Jones and Japanese sta r T akashi M urakam i, tied for se­ cond only one stroke back at 136. 
Defending cham pion Ben Crenshaw had another 71 and also was at 142. 
Champ 
KO’d 

MILAN, Italy (AP) — Britain’s Alan 
Minter captured the 
European middleweight boxing crown with a fifth- round knock out of Italian Germane Val- secchi Friday night. 

The 26-year-old B ritish challenger ended the fight at 2:49 of the round with a hard left hook It was the second tim e the Italian had gone dew n in the round. 
The bout w as held at the M ilan Indoor Sports 
Palace before 8,ooo spectators. 
V alsecehl, 28, who won the title last year, went down early in the fifth under a barrage of quick lefts and rights. The Italian responded with two rights to 
M inter’s face after the first knockdown, but they carried little power. 
M inter, landing punches alm ost at will, pum m eled 
Valsecchi in the second round, and the cham pion’s face was badly bruised and his eyes were swollen after the round.

Cage pairings set 

Pairings have been set for the Class z\AAA 
Regional Girls Basketball Tournament at Blossom 
Athletic Center Feb. 19. 
Winners of four bidistrict games to be played no later than Feb 15 will advance to the regional meet 
The Districts 25-26 winner will play the 27-28 winner at IO a m. Feb. 19, with the noon game to follow matching the 29-3o bidistrict champ against the 31-32 winner. 
Finals will be at 8 p m. the same day. 
The Class AAAA regional boys tournament will be held March 5 at Blossom Athletic C enter (and Alamo 
Stadium Gym if a North East team is involved). 
However, the University of Texas at San Antonio will request of the University Interscholastic League that it be the host for both Class AAAA hoys’ and girls’ regionals on a permanent basis beginning next year, UTSA Athletic Director Eudy Davalos saLd 
Friday.

 p p 

Clem ens takes title 
The unbeaten Clemens girls clinched the Dis­ trict 32-AAAA champion­ ship Friday night with a 
67-44 victory over Roose­ velt at Blossom Athletic 
Center. 
The Buffs chalked up their 29th straight victory with one game left in the regular season. An 18-1o second-quarter margin broke a first-period deadlock and propelled them to the league crown in their first year of Class 
AAAA competition. They won the 14-AAA East 
Zone title last year. 
In boys’ play, South­ side and Lee were the big winners, Southside stop­ ping Gonzales, 79-71, to force a tie between thosi teams for the 13-AAA 
East Zone lead and Lee whipping Seguin. 72-67, in a key District 32-AAAA result that leaves 
MacArthur and Roo­ sevelt in first place at 

J-o. 

Satu rd ay blate 

• O Y 5

G IR LS 
No g a m e s sched uled 
Gliebe tops iii 
Bass 

HUNTINGTON (A P ) 
— Dave Gliebe of Stock­ ton, Calif., won Hie first 
American Anglers Pro 
Bass Tournament Friday with a three-day total catch of 
52-pounds, 
4-ounces. 
Gliebe fought of the challenge of 1o9 anglers to win the $5,ooo first place money in the 
Skeeter Texas National event on Sam Rayburn 
Lake.

JUDSON’S David Nurse grabs rebound 

PHOTO BY H .M . DEAN , JR 
Girls

District 28-A A 

Rohde loses meet 
HARLINGEN (A P) - Jack W il­ liams, one of the top amateurs in West. 
Texas for the past 25 years, said before winning the 25th annual Life Begins at 
4o Golf tournament that he would be satisfied with a par 72. 
The 46-year-old Plainview native, who shared the first round lead in this rain-abbreviated senior amateur tour­ nament with Fred Rohde of San An­ tonio at 74, fell three strokes shy of his goal Friday but his score of 75 enabled him to emerge with a one-stroke vic­ tory over 1972 champion Jim Cason of 
Harlingen. 
Williams, a former Texas Christian 
University golfer withe 87 career vic­ tories, finished at 5-over-149 while 
Cason was winding up at 6-over-15o after posting a 74 Friday on the wa­ terlogged Harlingen Country Club course 
Rohde, a nine-year veteran of UBA 4o play, blew his chance of winning when he three-putted his final hole, a 
362-yard par 4. Ile finished at five- over-par 77 to place third at 151. 
Beden, who won in match play last year, shot a 78 Friday to finish at nine-over-153 for fourth place. 
Friday’s finals were played in sunny 
65 degree weather — a sharp contrast to Wednesday’s round which unfolded in chilly 5o degree temperature and a steady drizzle. Monday, Tuesday and 
Thursday rounds were all postponed due to rain. 
Maurice Wilson of Dallas, who put together three straight LBA 4o vic­ tories beginning in 1969, rebounded from an opening round 81 to shoot one-overpar 73 for a fifth place finish at 154 
Pistons hot 
DETROIT (/VP) - Center Bob Lan ler scored 4o points and pulled down 21 rebounds Friday night to lead the 
Detroit Pistons to a 124-111 National 
Basketball Association victory over the 
Denver Nuggets. 
Issei, the starting center in the NBA 
All-Star game Feb. 13, scored 38 points for the Nuggets w hile Thompson added 
3o.

KANSAS CITY (AP) - Austin Carr scored a season-high 29 points, includ­ ing two crucial free throws with eight seconds left in the game, to lead 
Cleveland to a 1o2-1o1 National Bas­ ketball Association victory over Kan­ sas City Friday night.

Robbing Peter to pay Paul 

Son Antonio'EXPRESS-NEWS- 
Celt*s 
La A t o r s 

Members of the Senate fi­ nance co m m ittee are eyeing park fund number 31 to help the 
Texas Parks and Wildlife De­ p artm en t out of its financial predicament. 

Clayton G arrison, executive director of the d e p a rtm e n t, appeared before the co m m ittee this week to ask that m ore than $5 m illion be resto red to the r e ­ quested tw o-year budget of $117.5 m il­ lion. 
G arriso n said he found c o m m itte e m e m b e rs “ very recep tiv e.” He added that m e m b e rs are looking at p ark fund 
31, w h ic h g e ts its m o n e y fro m th e penny-a-pack tax on cigarettes, to ease the cu rren t financial strain 
T h e c i g a r e t t e ta x m o n e y is e a r ­ m a rk ed for acquisition, p lan ning and developm ent of state p a rk s If the le­ g is la tu re a d d s p a rk op era tio n to the list, the funds now being spent on this item can be used in other a re a s of the d ep artm en t 

Garrison said fund 31 now has about 
$6 million over and above the amount programmed and that he feels the fund will have accumulated approximately 
SIS million by the end of 1979 over and above what is appropriated for co n ­ struction 

T his is a solution to the im m ed ia te financial pro b lem s of the d ep a rtm e n t, but it is not n e c e s s a rily the best solu­ tio n . D ip p in g in to fu n d 31 fo r th e operation of p ark s will reduce av aila­ ble funds for aequistion of additional p a rk s and th e d e v e lo p m e n t of those already purchased. 
The sales tax plan 

G a rriso n su g g ested a plan to com nu ttee m e m b e rs which, in m y opinion, w ould be f a r m o r e b en e fic ial to all users of the outdoors even though it, too. is a m a tte r of robbing P eter to pay 
Paul. 
T he plan, w hich drew no com m en t from co m m ittee m e m b e rs, would e a r ­ m a rk existing state sales taxes on out­ door p ro d u c ts — g u n s, a m m u n itio n , rods, reels, lures, boats, m oto rs, etc. 
— for the fish and wildlife divisions of the state agency. 

Garrison estim ate that this would amount to between $8 and $1o million per year. It would, in effect, return sales taxes — in a different form — to 
Texans who paid them. 

It would not m ean new taxes 
While finance c o m m itte e m e m b e rs are pondering the financial problem of the d e p a rtm e n t, let us hope they will m a k e up th e ir m in d s to h elp d efeat 

H ouse Bill 6o2 by A n d rew B a k e r of 
G alveston, w hich would elim in ate a l i i s a l t w a t e r f i s h in g li c e n s e s ( e x c e p t com m ercial) P assag e of such a m e a ­ s u re w ould cost th e d e p a r t m e n t a p ­ proxim ately $1.3 million p e r year. 
One m ust w onder about B a k e r’s in­ tentions, especial since a n o th e r mea-, sure of his, IPB. BOI. calls for splitting p ark s and wildlife into two agencies. 
New Guerrero lodge 

B ob T o n k in of B r o w n s v il le , w ho operated a fishing lodge at La P esea has opened one called La R e ta m a on 
Lake G uerrero. 
Tonkin says he has accom m od atio ns for 4o people, six p erson s to a cabin, plu s a r e s ta u r a n t, 15-foot fib e rg la s s b a ss b o a ts, 4o h o rs e p o w e r M e r c u ry m otors and guides. 

La R eta m a is located od the old highw ay out of Victoria toward Old 
Padilla, the town now flooded by the lake. Prices are $75 per day per per­ son. which in clu d es lod gin g, m ea ls, guides, ice, and drinks on the boat. If an an g ler b rin g s bis own boat, the price is $35 per day. 

T h e c a m p h a s p lace s to p a rk self- c o n ta in e d re c r e a tio n a l v e h ic le s and eventually will be equ ipp ed w ith full hookups. 
“ We are set up to take c a re of travel a r r a n g e m e n t s fro m th e b o r d e r and back, either by c a r or a ir tax i,” Tonkin said, “ and this hunting season we will be open to both w bitew ing h u n ters and fish erm en .” 
Tonkin has a 24-hour an sw erin g s e r ­ vice in B ro w n sv ille , AC512-541-8412. 
His m ailing a d d re ss for r e s o n ations is 
P.O. Box 3763, B row nsville 78521).

7 4o to play.
