As a 4-chonnel unit, it offers excellent reprod­ uction of discrete tapes and professional 4-channel recording from any source within your 4-channel sys­ tem. It can be integrated just as easily in a 2-chan­ nel system for extraordinarily fine results. With the 
Ookorder 714o, multi-track recording with all its unique possibilities, is available to the musician and composer for tho first time at a moderate price. With 
Multi-Sync it is possible to record four separate tracks individually and in perfect 'sync' with each other or to re-rocord any frock at any time in 'sync' with the

Dan Cook 

Cowens w on’t let^ other shoe fall 

Some of us keep waiting for Dave Cowens to drop the other shoe but evidently he intends to wear it on Feb. 13 in Milwaukee. 
From here it’s difficult to understand how 
Boston’s top basketball player can justify the thinking that must be going on in his own noggin. Dave, as most fans know, quit early in the season because he had lost his enthusiasm for the gam e. 
Well, that’s what he said, anyway. 

H 
San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday Feb 5 I 977 
Trinity, 
Rattlers in action 

The St. M ary’s Rattlers will be in the state capital Saturday night as the Big 
State Conference race enters the se­ cond half of its season. 
The Rattlers (16-5, 4-1) will battle 
Huston-Tillotson (5-11) at 7:3o p.m. in 
Austin as all six teams are scheduled to be in league action. 
In the biggest gam e of the night, league-leading Texas Lutheran (16-7. 
5-o) tests an eight-game win streak against potent Southwestern (1o-8. 2-3) at 7:3o p.m. in Seguin. 
East Texas Baptist (12-13, 3-2) will try to stay in distance of the leaders against St. E d w ard ’s (5-16. o-5) in 
Austin 

The Trinity Tigers (3-13) will also be iii action at home, m eeting LeTour- neau at 7:3o p.m. at Sams Center. The junior varsity team s of the two schools will clash at 5:311 p.m. 
Trinity, which will have the services of Jeff Spillane and Gerardo Marquez, who have who have been out with injuries, defeated LeTourneau earlier 

 i i i the season. 97-82, in Longview. 

Iii other gam es involving city and area college team s Saturday night San 
Jacinto will be at St. Philip’s at 7:3o p in., Stephen F. Austin (9-12, 5-4) will be at Southwest Texas (6-15, 4-5) at 
7:3o p.m.; Sam Houston (7-13, 3-6) will lie at Texas A&l (11-9, 3-6); Temple will be at Laredo JC at 7:3o p m .; 
H ouston B a p tist will be at 
Pan 
American (13-5) at 8 p.m. in Edinburg, the Pan American women vs ill be at St 
Mary's at 5 p.m. and the Trinity, SAC, 
A&I and SWT women will continue action iii the Baylor Tournament in 
Waco 

The Rattlers will probably start Roy 
Leggett (9.o) and Leon Walls (9 7) at the guards, Bobby Reid (16.7) at a forward and Mike Cunningham (9.5) and Larry Gooding (6.1) at the posts. 

Sports Scoreboard 

The quarter of a million dollars in sa­ lary lie receives every year failed to motivate him enough so he hit the rack and sashayed over to a racetrack to hire on as some sort of an official. 

That’s his business. There’s nothing in our Constitution that says everyone over 6-9 with good hands and fast feet must play basketball. Naturally, his salary stopped when he stopped. No play, no pay. Nobody was too critical. 
To the contrary, most folks were on 
D a v e ’s side. The poor guy had just burned himself out. That little fire that glows in the burner of all great ath­ letes and com petitors had just s i m ­ mered to coals so ( owens looked for other wavs to carn his daily bread. 

But while Cowens was negotiating himself a new career around the race­ track. the Celtics were wallowing iii more defeats than wins and trying to regroup and rebuild. 
Then, just as sudden as he had left the team, Cowens rejoined the Celtics.

<«olf 

Holla might he a candidate for top un­ ion official of 1977. 

T h is isn 't to knock 
Dave for quitting—anti returning. But it is to question his decision to show up iii 
Milwaukee on Feb. Ll and accept an honor that the lowest sub on the worst team deserves more. 
Tough question 
Here s the toughest basketball ques­ tion ut the month. What happened to 
Dave DeBusschere. com m issioner of the ABA, after his league folded and survivors joined the NBA? 

(live up? Me too. Some say he's do­ ing “ a little p ro m o tio n al work tor som ebody in either Detroit or New 
York.” But nobody around here seems to know exactly what happened to the guv who played such an important role iii helping to get the ABA and N B A together. 

This seems strange because Dave is one of the most unusual talents ever to grace the s|x»rts scene. 
But now, at .'17. DeBusschere seems to hav e dropped out of the sports scene and not many know what he’s doing, if anything. 
Reeves’ refusal 
T h e r e ’s so m eth in g stra n g e about that coaching situation i i i A tlanta. 
We’re talking football now, not b as­ ketball 

Fddic Le Ba ran was named general m anager of the Falcons one day and the next day he offered the head c o a c h in g job to h is old pal. D an 
Beeves, Dallas Cowboy assistant. Dan turned it dow n, c l a i m in g that it 
“wasn't attractive enough.” 

Two days later Los Angeles assistant 
Legman Bennett, obviously Atlanta's second choice, accepted the job and 
LeBaron told one and all that Bennett's contract made him “ one of the highest paid head couches in the N FL.” 

T h is poses a lot of questions. Did 
Beeves turn down that kind of offer to stay with D a l l a s as one of nine assistants? Did Atlanta just make a token offer to Beeves and then push the big goodies at Bennett? Does Beeves 
(eel that he’s first in line at D a lla s should Tom Landry quit? What makes 
LeBaron think that an untested head eoaeh like Beeves or Bennett can turn around a lousy program like Atlanta has shown for years? 

Maybe Bennett will whip up an in­ stant miracle so Sun Antonio’s Tommy 
Noins. iii the twilight of a long career as an Atlanta linebacker, can still get iii one season xx itll a winning pro team.

C a r c o n in slow 

Car operating costs rose 3.3 per 

 cent during 197b — the smallest in­ crease in the three years since the oil embargo. Without the insurance in­ crease of 3o per cent (largest in his­ to ry), operating outlays actu ally uould have dropped by a fraction of a cent.

SPORTY MAZDA transmission for 1977 is available with 5-speed manual or 3-speed 
; automatic 
Comfort still king 

SPtClAl TO IMI f XPRESS NT WS 
DEAK BORN, Midi. - Grand­ dad wore a hat in his automobile and never had to worry about crushing it against the roof. Ile could also stretch his legs from the rear seat but did it from an un­ comfortable position over the rear axle. 
Better leg and head room wore about the only space advantages the old buggies had o u t today’s oars. according to tho 
Automotive Information Council. 
Los Henry, transportation curator at 
Homy Cord Museum here says; "C ull si/e cars may ho shrinking in exterior m / o . but interior comforts are still head and shoulders above the cramped and jostling ruffs the early autos offered." 
Front seat hip room in 1977 interme­ diate or mid-si/e cars ranges from r»r> to 5H inches. Full-size or regular ears span 55 to HO inches. The curator, for comparison. put a tape measure on several of the more 

 hull siz<> (firs m a y In> shrinking in exterior size, hut interior a n n f o r ts ore still h e a d a n d s h o u ld ers a ho re the c r a m p e d a n d jo stlin g rides e a rly autos offered' 

 than ‘inn antique and classic cars in the museum. 
A 1923 Chevrolet coupe and a 192o Model 
A Cord each offered 44 inches across the front seat. Aiming the so-called larger 

 e a r s of the twenties, a Nash measured 4o inches and a 1923 Lincoln had only 42 

 i i i * l i e s of hip room. Fierce-Arrow, one of the first of the luxury entries, had a 
44-inch front seat. 
Automakers realized early i i i the game that people tam e in all sizes. Credit 
Maxwell, a forerunner of Chrysler, with introducing the first adjustable front seat in 1914. That attracted more ladies to the 

 automobile, otilv two years after the debut of the self-starter, the invention that really put women behind the wheel. 
Among all the cars Les Henry taped, one of the widest was an entry that quickly failed. The Tucker, announced shortly after World W a r II, boasted a front span of HI inches. Despite tremen­ dous fanfare. Tucker only produced a few pilot models before the company col­ lapsed. 
Except for the Austin Bantam, a very small car, there1 was really only one size of automobile until Nash came out with the 1959 Rambler. That car was re-intro­ duced about seven years later as Rambler 
American. It wasn’t until late 1959. the 
I HUO model year, that (leneral Motors, 
Ford and Chrysler really began selling a variety of sizes. 
Henry concedes the very first cars, like the single-cylinder Duryea and Ford s liuadricycle, were unchallenged in head­ room space. Literally, the sky was the lim it. Completely enclosed cars didn t arrive until 1914 with the birth of Dodge 

By JIM ABBOTT 

AUTO tDITOl* 
People who have been saying the rotary engine is dead should take a good look at the newest rotary powered ear from Japan, the 
Mazda RX-3 SP. 
Built by Toyo Kogyo. Ltd., the new coupe has undergone several design mo­ difications from last year’s RX-3 model. 
The RX-3 SP will go on sale in March aud will be priced under $4,o9o (P O K. — tax. license, freight and optional equipment are extra). 
In announcing the new car Mazda offi­ cials said, "The 1977 RX-3 SP reaffirms our com m itm ent to produce ro tary powered automobiles for the person who is looking for outstanding performance, a smooth, quiet power plant and a high quality automobile.” 
Not only does Mazda say it w ill continue to produce rotary engine cars hut that it has plans to introduce a rotary-powered sports car for the 1978 model year. 
Savanna 
Motor racing fans w ill recogniee the 
RX-3 SP as the Japanese ‘Savanna.’ The 
Savanna has captured more than 119 vic­ tories on race circuits i i i the past five years and continues to set new records. 
The RX-3 S P inherits many of the Sa­ vanna’s characteristics. The racing Sa­ vanna has a top speed of 114 miles an hour and can do the standing start quarter- tnile in 1H 9 seconds. 
While the performance of many auto­ mobiles has declined because of increas­ ingly stringent exhaust emission control standards, safety regulations and fuel economy competition, the RX-3 SP will rank near the top of high performance cars sold in the United States. 
Highway mileage 

The RX-3 SP meets the 49-state domes­ tic em issions standards, and still acheived an Environm ental Protection 
Agency rating of 3o miles per gallon on the highway and 23 miles per gallon in 

CLASSIFIED DISPLAY 
CLASSIFIED DISPLAY 
6TU1TIU5 B W LAY 

NEW MAZDA RX-3 SP looks match its performance 
Pros, not kids, hike auto thefts 

SPtCIAl TO IMI IXPRthS NT WH 
D L I HOIT — Even though car buyers have purchased over SI billion worth of anti-theft devices on their new cars since 
19o9, an all-time record of one million auto thefts will he sci this veal*. 

The steering column locks, the ignition key buzzer systems, the anti theft warn­ ing systems, the vehicle identification numbers and several other devices have defeated the teen-age "joy riders" who stoic 79 per cent of the cars five Nears ago 

But these devices are now being easily defeated by the numerous professional theft rings who are responsible for over two-thirds of all auto thefts today 
For profit 
Jim Dido, vehicle security specialist for 
(ieiieral Motors, says: 
"It s no longer theft for joy-riding. Ifs theft for profit. It s caused bv the social scene, the arrival of narcotics everywhere and the need to find a way lo support that habit. Also responsible is the develop­ ment of sophisticated auto theft rings worldwide. They know that thev can get 

~ciA>sirtft, dism ay 
^ 
T 

 involved m this kind of activity with practically no risk 
So the thing the auto thieves are be­ ginning to see, particularly the smart ones, is that they can involve themselves 

 i i i a low-risk, high-payoff type of criminal activity aud they are just automatically going to make motor vehicle thefts to get the money. 
Social change 
"N ow the social change comes along with the new profile of theft, theft for profit, and this causes tile smart thief to develop sophisticated ways to not only defeat the security system, hut to gener­ ate the right kind of a network for mar­ keting, as well as the registration and titling aspect.” 
According to Dote, there are other fac­ tors responsible for doubling the number of ear thefts i i i the past decade Among these are the general moral decay, the greater value of automobiles (especially 

 i i i foreign countries), the growing market for stolen cars and p articu larly stolen auto parts and a general rise in criminal activity.

San Antonio E X P R E S S -N E W S — Saturday February 5 I 9 7 7 MAZDA 

Chrysler’s Auto Roller was designed to test fuel systems which, under federal regulations, are allowed to leak only a minimal amount after a vehicle crashes and rolls over. Test engineers can drive a vehicle onto the 
Auto Roller and rotate it 36o degrees 

Coatioaed from Page I 

 city driving. 
Considering the performance of the ro­ tary engine, those figures are very im ­ pressive, and should put to rest forever the fallacy that the Mazda is a “ gas-hog.” 
Styling changes for the RX-3 SP include the addition of mat-black bum pers, windshield wipers and center pillar. The interior carries out the black theme, with plaid fabric seats. Also standard are re­ clining bucket seats, carpeting .heated rear window, center console and tinted glass. 
Toyo Kogyo is .Japan’s third largest automobile maker and 12th in size among car builders worldwide. It also has the distinction of being the world’s largest mass producer of the rotary engines. 
O p tio n s 
In its basic unadorned offering, the 
Mazda RX-3 SF* is the least expensive rotary powered car sold in this country. 
However, there are several options the sporty car driver will surely want to make his RX-3 SF’ stand out in the crowd. 
Paint, tape and stripe options identify the RX-3 SP so that no one will mistake it for anything else. Functional front air dam, and rear spoiler also add to the car’s appearance. Louvered covers can be placed over the rear windows. 
Steel belted tires are standard. There is a choice of 5-speed manual transmission or an automatic. The front disc, rear drum, brakes are vacuum assisted. 

CIASM'IfD DISPLAY 
CLASSI?KO D U P U Y ' 

N e w O ld s 

The 1977 Tornado XS is Olds­ mobile s newest addition to the personal luxury car line. The 
XS features a large panoramic wrap-around rear window and an electrically-operated Astro- roof. The long Toronado lines are accented by a special paint stripe, and a landau roof’is fea­ tured.

VALENTINE LOVE LINES 

Tell that special someone, "I love you,” in the Valentine Love tines that will appear in the Classifi­ ed Section of the Express-News on 
M onday, February I 4th.

Box

Thursday, February 1oth. 

You will enjoy the low cost as much as your Special Someone will appreciate your thoughtfulness. The rate is 2 5 C per line with a minimum of four lines, or $1 OO minimum. 
Large type for headlines at extra cost.

SHEETMETAL MECHANICS 

Continued growth of Swearingen Aviation corporation has created o demand for additional employees desiring careers in aircraft manufacturing. 

Swearingen has immediate requirements for experienced Sheetmetal Mechanics. These positions require 2 to 3 years experience performing structural assembly and aircraft sheetmetal in- 
> striation. These positions offer storting rates from $3.49 to $4.19 per hour, automatic 9o day In* creases, annual general increases, and excellent working conditions.

Swearingen is a growth oriented aircraft manufacturer competing in the general aviation in­ dustry. We are committed to a policy of promotion from within and offering employees op­ portunities for advancement based on their individual ability and performance. 

 lf you ore interested in knowing more about these openings and a possible future with 
Swearingen, telephone Paul Grande, Personnel Administrator, at 824-9421, Ext. 319. You may also apply in person at the employment office, Swearingen Aviation Corporation, International 
Airport, San Antonio, Tx. (come East on Bitters Road past Blossom Athletic Center, turn right on NE entrance rood.)

Figure skater Peggy Fleming sits with her son, Andrew 
Thomas Jenkins, at her home in Atherton, C alif., 
Friday. Peggy is married to Dr. G reg Jenkins. The baby was born at Stanford University Hospital Sun­ day. Miss Fleming won a gold medal at the 1968 
Olympics after winning five U.S. championships and three world titles. — AP Wirephoto 
East Central votes study of sewage 

By IJ Z SH’K ET 
East Central School 
District board members 
Frid a y night voted to form a com m ittee of three board members and district citizens to study seuage problems. 
In a special session, trustees heard a report on the sewage system si­ tuation from .Joe Pyle of 
Sceigrnan and Pyle 
Pyle offered a cost es­ timate of $292,ooo. 

Iii other action, board members defeated a mo­ tion to send d istrict representatives to a training program on Wo­ men's Equality in Edu­ cation. 
Request 

Nancy Hagen, curricu­ lum coordinator, re­ quested the board to send up to three teachers or staff m em bers to the three-day workshop con­ ducted by the Region XX 
Service ( enter. 
Mrs. Hagen said the training will enable par­ ticipants to help the dis­ trict avoid violations of 
Title IX which deals with discriminatory practices against women in educa­ tion. 
The program, she said, also would count towards 

 required in-service training. 
Leading the opposition, 
Dr Chester East in said 
Ik' failed to see the need for such training. 
Dr. East in said the program would create a mini-gestapo system with teachers serving as watchdogs.

Canals from 
Alaska could help deserts 

P A SA D E N A . 
Calif. 
(A P ) — Canals carrying water across Canada from Alaska could trans­ form 
Am erican and 
Mexican deserts to "the breadbasket of the w orld.” a scientist bel lev es 
Dr Nathan W . Snyder. chief scientist for un en­ gineering firm tiiat lias spent 
$1 m inion lo develop the proposal, said the potential ben­ efits of increased farm ­ land, recreation and bv- droeleotric power justiiv its consideration. 
That's if $ KH) billion could he raised to pay for it, if the* governments concerned could agree lo it and if engineers could solve environm ental problems likely to arnse. 

Nine years 

W ale r could be delivered to Am erican desert areas within nine years of construction start, Snyder said. Once completed, he added, tin* system could boost the 
American gross national product by $45o billion a year aud Canada s by up to HIO billion 
S n y d e rs firm , tile 
Ralph M Parsons l o .an international engineering conglom erate. first released its conceptual study IU years ago It was resubmitted to the public
